2017-07-01 00:35:24

set the channel description: Discussions for the cucumber-ruby developers

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-01 00:37:39

@brasmusson I’m thinking to move all of the Event types (and the EventBus) into the new cucumber-events gem (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/event-protocol-test-results/event-protocol/ruby) and have that gem be a dependency of both the core and of the front-end. So all the events are defined in one place. WDYT?

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber
cucumber - Cucumber parent project - keeping all implementations in sync
brasmusson
2017-07-03 12:09:59

*Thread Reply:* @matt-SmartBear The question is if it is possible to define useful event in the Cucumber parent project. Defining events do often make detailed assumptions about flow and implementation. For instance a "test run started" event with test count assumes collecting all pickles/test cases before executing any of them. A "test case prepared" event assumes that the preparation comes long before the "test case started". A "pickle dispatched for execution" event would be useful in a distributed execution scenario, but not in a single treaded scenario.

brasmusson
2017-07-01 00:37:44

@brasmusson has joined the channel

Dana Scheider (they/he)
2017-07-03 16:48:25

Hey everybody, I'm getting Travis failures due to Rubocop on my PR (#1138 on cucumber-ruby), but when I grep for the offenses locally I don't get any results. Rubocop is pointing to files in the scripts directory, but that directory doesn't exist on my machine. Anybody know what's up?

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-03 23:21:18

@Dana Scheider (they/he) I’ve been building scripts to help merge PRs and add new maintainers. There are now three of them on master. I’ve been a bit hasty about waiting for the build before merging them and have introduced Rubocop failures a couple of times.

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-03 23:21:36

Sorry!

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-03 23:23:28

I’ve just fixed them (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/commit/3cbf87aa2ff6a882d7fe84f5851558327a4c05e3 and https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/commit/f18b4c001e456bb9cb17b5426eebe62c3bf0785b) and I think master is now clean

GitHub
Fix rubocop issues · cucumber/cucumber-ruby@3cbf87a
cucumber-ruby - Simple, human collaboration
GitHub
Fix refactoring mistake (thanks rubocop) · cucumber/cucumber-ruby@f18b4c0
cucumber-ruby - Simple, human collaboration
Dana Scheider (they/he)
2017-07-03 23:24:01

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-03 23:29:33

enkessler
2017-07-04 16:06:52

For PRs, is there a preference between rebasing the PR against master or merging master into the PR?

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-05 00:16:52

@enkessler personally I prefer rebasing my own PRs so that the commits tell a neat story, but I don’t have a strong preference. Does anyone else?

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-05 00:41:27

So everyone there are three new scripts in our repo to help us do repo maintenance chores:

1) scripts/update-history &lt;PULL_REQUEST_NUMBER&gt; will insert a line into History.md based on the info in the given pull request. Note that the PR must have one of the three blue type: labels so the script knows which section (bugfix, feature, refactoring) to put it into. It doesn’t currently do anything automatic about breaking changes, you’ll still need to document those yourself before committing the file. 2) scripts/invite-collaborator &lt;GITHUB_LOGIN&gt; for adding new collaborators to the team 3) scripts/create-new-collaborator-welcome-issue &lt;GITHUB_LOGIN&gt; &lt;PULL_REQUEST_NUMBER&gt; for creating an issue to welcome a new collaborator

I’m still not 100% settled on what our policy should be for inviting new collaborators. Doing it based on just one pull request almost seems a bit needy / over-friendly. What do other people think?

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-05 00:42:20

@aida what’s your perspective? Was it a surprise to be invited to join the team based on just one PR? intimidating? welcoming? somewhere in the middle?

aida
2017-07-05 00:42:23

@aida has joined the channel

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-05 00:42:31

@aida ^^

enkessler
2017-07-05 05:02:05

@matt-SmartBear I've done both but I think that rebasing can mess up the conversation in a PR.

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-05 06:16:03

*Thread Reply:* @enkessler is that so? I hadn’t noticed. What happens?

enkessler
2017-07-05 06:21:36

*Thread Reply:* It's a guess. I suppose that I could try it and see what happens.

enkessler
2017-07-05 06:23:29

*Thread Reply:* I wouldn't worry as much if I was doing the PR from my own fork of the repo but because it is in the main repo and theoretically other people might want to add commits to the PR instead of just commenting on it, I am inclined to follow the general rebasing rule of 'never, once it is public'.

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-05 07:51:46

*Thread Reply:* OK, so like as soon as you’ve had comments on it, you should use merge rather than rebase.

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-05 07:51:59

*Thread Reply:* I think we should write that up in CONTRIBUTING.md, seems like a good principle.

enkessler
2017-07-05 08:05:52

*Thread Reply:* I'll rebase my profile loader fix PR real quick, just to see what happens. It's had a good amount of comments on it, although no one has added commits.

enkessler
2017-07-05 08:23:24

*Thread Reply:* Nevermind. You've already merged it. That is definitely too late to mess with the branch/PR. 😉

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-05 08:23:46

*Thread Reply:* 😄

brasmusson
2017-07-05 05:44:06

@enkessler @matt-SmartBear There is also the third option, to have Github to squash merge the PR into the trunk. Then the whole change is added to the trunk in one commit, but the PR branch is not changed.

matt-SmartBear
2017-07-05 06:15:29

*Thread Reply:* @brasmusson I thought @enkessler was talking about how to keep your own PR up to date with master.

enkessler
2017-07-05 06:20:42

*Thread Reply:* That is what I was referring to, yes. How to handle keeping a PR up to date because master is always a moving target.

brasmusson
2017-07-05 10:12:53

*Thread Reply:* I feel that the general preference in the Cucumber project is rebase, and not merge from master to pull-request branch. IRCC Github also has problems with showing only the changes made on the pull request (and not mix them up with changes merged from the master), so that also points to using rebase.

enkessler
2017-07-05 10:15:31

*Thread Reply:* Yeah, I've seen it mess up displaying changes after a merge before.

enkessler
2017-07-05 10:16:04

*Thread Reply:* I don't recall if it retains comments correctly after a rebasing. Have you seen it done recently?

brasmusson
2017-07-05 11:43:38

*Thread Reply:* I tested it just a minute ago (not so much with a rebase, but rather a complete restart), GitHub seems to keep the comments on the pull request conversation tab (for instance https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/pull/1161#pullrequestreview-47740957), but when you click on the "view changes" button GitHub cannot find them, however when you go to the file changed tab you can see the comment again (here https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/pull/1161/files#r125359106).

GitHub
[Core] Use the test case duration in the JUnit Formatter. by brasmusson · Pull Request #1161 · cucumber/cucumber-jvm
Summary Let the JUnit Formatter use the duration of the test case result. Details Let the JUnit Formatter use the duration of the test case result instead of summing up the durations of the test st...
enkessler
2017-07-06 06:11:16

*Thread Reply:* Okay. I might try rebasing the next time the I have a PR.

enkessler
2017-07-06 06:11:18

*Thread Reply:* Thanks.

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-07-24 15:29:01

Hi @channel - Cucumber Expressions are landing in Cucumber-Ruby soon. Does anyone have a sizeable project they could take it for a spin with? More info here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1156

GitHub
Support Cucumber Expressions, ref #1002 by aslakhellesoy · Pull Request #1156 · cucumber/cucumber-ruby
Summary Support for Cucumber Expressions. Basic support Deprecate Transform (but try to make it work with current API) Add API for defining custom parameter types Print snippets as Cucumber Ex...
Aslak Hellesøy
2017-07-25 06:06:34

@channel I'd like to get some user feedback on Cucumber Expressions. I think the only way to do that is to make a release. Maybe v3.0.0.pre.2. Is there anything holding up a 3.0.0 release?

brasmusson
2017-07-25 06:29:40

*Thread Reply:* My current short list for a 3.0.0 release would be (some from the cukenspace workshop https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/archives/C5B8A9Q3H/p1498313949091649):

  • Rename events to past tense (s/ing/ed/g in event names from cukenspace)
  • TC count event optional (from cukenspace, see https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1082#issuecomment-310316166)
  • Selective activation of strict option (see https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1160)
  • Do not crash on ambiguous steps (however the ambiguous result code could wait), see https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1113 and https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1132 A v3.0.0.pre.2 could be done now (together with a pre of the cucumber-core gem)
Björn Rasmusson (https://cucumberbdd.slack.com/team/brasmusson)
<p>MoM for the Cucumber-Ruby 3.0.0 session: Must have:</p><ul><li>no lost events (#1041)</li><li>summary printout and exit code with --retry (#1044)</li><li>TC count event optional</li><li>s/ing/ed/g in event names</li> </ul> <p>Could have:</p><ul><li>Extract steps mechanims as gem</li><li>Test suite works on Windows</li> </ul> <p>Out of scope:</p><ul><li>Deprecate custom formatter that use legacy API</li><li>Deprecate remove wire protocol</li><li>PR to History script/bot</li> </ul>
Slack Conversation
GitHub
Add `test_run_starting` event to broadcast all test cases before a run by mattwynne · Pull Request #1082 · cucumber/cucumber-ruby
Any listener that wants to know how many test cases there will be (e.g. to display a progress bar) will need this information.
GitHub
Cucumber --retry option status 1 with strict mode causes --retry option to not be useful · Issue #1160 · cucumber/cucumber-ruby
@brasmusson - re: cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core#141 Tying this to --strict mode is overloading what --strict mode means and how developers are going to want to use the --retry option. Personally spea...
GitHub

Summary When ambiguous steps are encountered, Cucumber essentially crashes. No reports are generated and no other tests executed. It just dies. Expected Behavior All tests should be run and output ...

maxmeyer
2017-08-10 23:29:05

@maxmeyer has joined the channel

maxmeyer
2017-08-10 23:31:43

Hey, is there a output formatter available on cucumber-ruby which outputs runtime for scenarios? We face severe slow downs on jruby - even with --dev set - e.g. https://travis-ci.org/cucumber/aruba/builds/259526259. I would like to check, if there are some scenarios which take way too long to finish.

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-08-11 00:54:10

@maxmeyer --format usage shows you the slowest stepdefs and where they are used.

Gem
2017-08-11 14:05:15

@maxmeyer Once you run things above to identify which finish in what time, you can add tags like @fast or @slow and do runs based off those tags. 🙂

matt-SmartBear
2017-08-11 14:48:34

@maxmeyer the cucumber build is also dreadfully slow due to JRuby. If you get any insights into what’s causing yours please share.

matt-SmartBear
2017-08-11 14:49:04

My guess is the startup time on the scenarios that have to fork a new process.

maxmeyer
2017-08-11 15:02:16

Thanks @Aslak Hellesøy I was not sure if this was the formatter I was looking for.

maxmeyer
2017-08-11 15:08:43

@matt-SmartBear This might cause the issue. For now I see no further configuration options for jruby to optimize the build. If this really is only the startup time, I see not that many options to improve the build time. at least if leave the test suite as it is now - and there are still a lot of tests for our API undocumented. So it won't get any better. I hope to find some tests where some loops cause a too long running time. I wonder if something has changed on Travis' side which cause that delays. Have you tried their legacy build system with jruby?

maxmeyer
2017-08-11 15:09:59

@Gem Yes, if I can identify some slow scenarios.

Gem
2017-08-11 15:10:23

👍

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-08-11 15:27:32

@maxmeyer a couple of years ago I added a mechanism that allows you to not have to fork a new (j)ruby process for each scenario. Is that still around?

matt-SmartBear
2017-08-11 16:06:32

yes it is @Aslak Hellesøy, and it’s a godsend. There’s still a handful of scenarios that don’t work with it for various reasons.

matt-SmartBear
2017-08-11 16:07:05

I dunno @maxmeyer. We could also try CircleCI to see if it’s any better.

matt-SmartBear
2017-08-11 16:07:24

How long do the JRuby tests take to run locally? I’m not sure I’ve tried it myself since I spotted the problem on CI.

maxmeyer
2017-08-11 23:27:46

Not sure, running it locally is on my list. What might work is to run the very "outer" Cucumber/RSpec inprocess as it is only used to run the examples. Thanks @Aslak Hellesøy.

Gem
2017-08-14 09:08:37

@Aslak Hellesøy thanks for the add!

Rich Downie
2017-08-16 12:10:45

@Rich Downie has joined the channel

Gem
2017-08-16 12:50:45

Just loaded up 3.0.0.pre.2 to try out expressions and immediately ran into an issue. hah

Gem
2017-08-16 12:51:10

I previously had this for a step: Given I want to request "&lt;caption_count&gt;" caption(s)

Gem
2017-08-16 12:52:22

Works fine on 2.4, but when I updated and switched the step to Given I want to request "{caption count}" caption(s) it interpreted the caption(s) paren as a capture group 😛

Gem
2017-08-16 12:52:25

Expression /^I want to request "([^"]**)" caption\(s\)$/ has 1 capture groups (["{caption count}"]), but there were 2 parameter types (["[^\"]**", "s\\"]) (Cucumber::CucumberExpressions::CucumberExpressionError)

Gem
2017-08-16 12:53:19

So, question: What do we want the behavior to be?

matt-SmartBear
2017-08-16 12:57:19

looks like a bug @Gem - the \s “capture group” looks escaped in the printed regexp to me

Gem
2017-08-16 12:57:58

Oh wait no.

Gem
2017-08-16 12:58:52

I hadn't changed my step def file correctly. I wanted to comment out the step to have cucumber suggest a new snippet but I commented the wrong step.

Gem
2017-08-16 12:59:01

Instead what it ran into was Given(/^I want to request "([^"]**)" caption\(s\)$/) do |caption_num|

Gem
2017-08-16 12:59:13

So, it's totally doing it right. 😄

Gem
2017-08-16 12:59:20

PEBKAC ftl

Gem
2017-08-16 13:00:19

The way 3.0 handles it is Given("I want to request {string} caption# (s)") do |string|

Gem
2017-08-16 13:00:52

Thanks though @matt-SmartBear!

matt-SmartBear
2017-08-16 13:01:09

👍

Gem
2017-08-16 19:37:36

Spending some good time digging into the cucumber-expressions-ruby code tonight! 😄

GitHub
Backward support for escaped parens in steps by jaysonesmith · Pull Request #253 · cucumber/cucumber
Summary When creating step def snippets from features that have parenthesis, cucumber can sometimes escape them with backslashes and this breaks the current 3.0 handling of step defs. Details Rema...
giel
2017-08-22 04:46:23

hi all

giel
2017-08-22 04:47:18

I'm noticing with cucumber 2.0 that docstring serialization on the wire protocol changed

giel
2017-08-22 04:47:56

it used to be serialized as just a regular JSON string, now instead it seems to be a serialization of https://docs.ruby-lang.org/en/2.4.0/Delegator.html

giel
2017-08-22 04:48:59

@giel uploaded a file: cucumber 2.0 serialization of docstring

cucumber 2.0 serialization of docstring
giel
2017-08-22 04:49:40

this breaks backwards compatibility and as a result causes breakage for (at least) cucumber-cpp when docstrings are used in scenarios

giel
2017-08-22 04:50:53

This looks to me like it's an accidental change, but I'd like to have that confirmed

olleolleolle
2017-08-22 04:52:33

@olleolleolle has joined the channel

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-08-22 04:52:53

Yes, that sounds like a regression @giel - can you create an issue please? WDYT @olleolleolle?

olleolleolle
2017-08-22 04:53:57

@Aslak Hellesøy It looks like a usage of SimpleDelegator changed things. https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=delegate&type= Not many hits. Should be investigatable.

Gem
2017-08-22 05:34:34

@Aslak Hellesøy I said it on the ticket, but I'll say it here too thanks for the guidance!

Gem
2017-08-22 05:34:40

I'll get it fixed up shortly

Gem
2017-08-22 05:44:39

All set @Aslak Hellesøy

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-08-22 06:12:18

@Gem - sorry - just had to do this: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/pull/254

GitHub
Cucumber expressions fix regexp parsing by aslakhellesoy · Pull Request #254 · cucumber/cucumber

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-06 03:39:03

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-06 03:43:12

brasmusson
2017-09-06 04:23:51

@Gem @matt-SmartBear KAC says "The same types of changes should be grouped", that some entries in the "Changed" group has a title prefix (Refactor:) goes against this guideline. Using a separate heading for "Refactorings" or "Developer Experience" comply better with the KAC guidelines.

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-06 04:31:16

OK @brasmusson then I think a separate section makes sense. I’d suggest keeping it broader than just “Refactoring” so we can include other things like improvements to build scripts etc.

2017-09-06 04:31:23

brasmusson
2017-09-06 04:35:54

The gist of the category seem to me to be things that the user is not affected by, but are valuable information to a contributor. I am not sure about the best name for such a category.

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-06 10:41:10

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-06 15:53:35

so @channel I have a puzzle.

According to the stats @Aslak Hellesøy has pulled together in https://github.com/cucumber/github-issue-stats/blob/master/CUCUMBER.md, the cucumber-ruby repo has gradually been accumulating more and more open issues since early 2015.

Right now there are 65 open issues, 26 open pull requests.

The oldest issue is from March 2013, and the oldest PR is from October 2015.

I’d really like to get this down to a more manageable amount of work-in-progress. And I’d like to change the system somehow so that we’re on a more sustainable footing, with us able to keep on top of the issues and deal with them reasonably quickly as they come in.

I’m looking for ideas for how we could achieve that. Please everyone chime in with your suggestions and let’s see if we can crack this problem!

GitHub
cucumber/github-issue-stats
github-issue-stats - Compute and visualise stats about GitHub issues
Gem
2017-09-06 15:56:47

I was looking through issues last night actually! haha

enkessler
2017-09-06 15:57:49

I wonder how many I am already involved in and haven't touched in a while...

enkessler
2017-09-06 16:02:00

Personally, I enjoy contributing to projects but I tend to always stop for one or two particular obstacles:

  1. I can't grab it and go. If at all possible, the bar for entry needs to be git clone, bundle install, and bundle exec rake.
  2. I can't figure out the internal workings and I can't get a hold of someone who knows them.
enkessler
2017-09-06 16:03:27

I've been That Guy on enough projects that 1 isn't as much of a problem as it used to be but 2 is more difficult to avoid. Having this Slack channel helps a lot, though.

enkessler
2017-09-06 16:04:30

We may not always be able to grab a core contributor but we can at least shout out that we are stuck and drop a link to our fork/PR.

enkessler
2017-09-06 16:06:20

At his point I'm really just mentally hitting a cap on projects. Even if I had the time and understanding, I don't think that I'd have the head space to be more than a sometimes contributor to Cucumber stuff. 10 open source projects is enough for me, thanks. 😉

Gem
2017-09-06 16:08:25

It's definitely tough to keep so many pots going

olleolleolle
2017-09-06 16:09:56

Issues without follow-up or labels on it - this opens a "mental loop" for me. needs triage, it hums.

Gem
2017-09-06 16:12:44

haha

Gem
2017-09-06 16:12:54

Attack @olleolleolle !

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-07 00:41:13

So @olleolleolle you’re saying you’d find it easier to work on issues if they’d been triaged by someone else?

olleolleolle
2017-09-07 00:42:36

*Thread Reply:* More like a psychological loop is opened: "I ought to do something here." But, the action to take may be unclear. No specific Label to add, no follow-up q to ask to have them specify clearer what their goal is, etc.

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-07 00:43:38

*Thread Reply:* So would it help to have a think about what our general process for issues should be? Like one of those flow charts they use in call centres? 🙂

olleolleolle
2017-09-07 00:45:37

*Thread Reply:* A possible solution to this could be for me to hone the CONTRIBUTING docs, adding a section on Triage (focusing on the "growing number of Issues over time" problem).

Actually, yes, call-centre or emergency-room triage is what comes to mind. "Does this have a Label? No? Do x to remedy that."

Many Issues posted are "type question". Using the issue tracker as a support mailing list.

olleolleolle
2017-09-07 00:46:56

*Thread Reply:* (Rambling, apologies.)

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-07 00:47:32

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-07 00:42:35

@enkessler so you’d finding the code is hard to navigate your way around and understand, and sometimes you get blocked because of that?

enkessler
2017-09-07 08:14:04

@matt-SmartBear Yep. It's understandable that an OS project that has been going for almost a decade is going to have some less than pretty areas of code. Part of it is also project structure. For example, sometimes the end to end of a problem goes through cucumber-ruby, into cucumber-ruby-core, and back again, which suddenly makes it cross project.

Gem
2017-09-07 09:10:12

I certainly understand that last parts @enkessler ! When I was tracking down an issue in 3.x with regex on step defs, The back trace went through cucumber, cucumber core, back to cucumber, and then to cucumber expressions. 😛

It was an eye opener and taught me a lot about how the project is architected, even if it made things a little more difficult initially.

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-07 12:49:26

So maybe it just comes down to https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1170

GitHub
Do not by default delay the execution of test cases by brasmusson · Pull Request #1170 · cucumber/cucumber-ruby
Summary Do not by default delay the execution of test cases until all have been processed through the filter chain. Details Do not by default delay the execution of test cases until all have been ...
brasmusson
2017-09-07 23:13:49

*Thread Reply:* A side effect of adding an event with the test count (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1082), was that test cases no longer are flowing through the the filter pipeline to be executed, but are batched instead. My understanding is the the "flowing through the filter pipeline" was one of the fundamental design principles of the rewrite to 2.0.0, so I recon that this side effect unwanted, this is what https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1167 and https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1170 is all about.

I would be ok with reverting https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1082 and consider an event with the test count after 3.0.0.

GitHub
Add `test_run_starting` event to broadcast all test cases before a run by mattwynne · Pull Request #1082 · cucumber/cucumber-ruby
Any listener that wants to know how many test cases there will be (e.g. to display a progress bar) will need this information.
GitHub
Make the TC count event optional · Issue #1167 · cucumber/cucumber-ruby
It is not a good idea to always stop all test cases in a filter before passing them on, because maybe a formatter that is interested in the test case count is used (from the cukenspace workshop), s...
GitHub
Do not by default delay the execution of test cases by brasmusson · Pull Request #1170 · cucumber/cucumber-ruby
Summary Do not by default delay the execution of test cases until all have been processed through the filter chain. Details Do not by default delay the execution of test cases until all have been ...
Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-07 13:01:07

I wonder if we need to fix 1190 and 1191 before 3.0.0 though - they're regressions.

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-07 13:01:35

Added to milestone

enkessler
2017-09-07 13:06:07

It's always nice to not release a known regression. 🙂

Gem
2017-09-07 13:14:42

Are there any other flavors that have released 3.0 or is the versioning completely different across them?

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-07 15:10:35

Release cadence and age of all flavours are different. They all differ slightly in several areas. The version numbers reflect their individual evolution, not conformance to a cross platform feature set or spec (which doesn't exist)

Gem
2017-09-07 15:12:40

Gotcha!

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-07 15:12:41

My long term vision is convergence by extracting libraries (gherkin, tag expressions, cucumber e pressions) and having then share a test suite. When most behaviour is extracted and converged, we may start to align version numbers. It's a long journey.

Gem
2017-09-07 15:13:14

Makes sense

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-07 15:13:43

We may even extract or build some parts that can be used cross platform, like formatters consuming events over pipes.

Gem
2017-09-07 15:14:58

Reminds me of Selenium/Appium 🙂

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-07 15:16:50

What part?

Gem
2017-09-07 15:17:52

Gem
2017-09-07 15:18:08

So ultimately it all ends up making the same call I think? haha

Gem
2017-09-07 15:19:18

Oh hai @cheezy !

Gem
2017-09-07 15:19:34

Do I have my understanding correct?

cheezy
2017-09-07 15:19:45

In the y versions of x.y the language bindings try to synchronize features but is is not always done.

cheezy
2017-09-07 15:20:27

The x versions are more careful and usually contain large updates.

cheezy
2017-09-07 15:20:47

Hello @Gem

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-07 15:20:57

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-07 15:21:22

Which means multiple ports in different languages

cheezy
2017-09-07 15:21:59

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-07 15:23:52

Cucumber will never require rpc or networking to talk to the code being tested. That would kill the subsecond feedback loop which all BDD practitioners rely on :-)

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-07 15:24:05

Hi @cheezy!

Gem
2017-09-07 15:24:34

Aslak Hellesøy

Gem
2017-09-07 15:26:03

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-17 13:49:46

enkessler
2017-09-17 13:49:52

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-17 13:50:22

It's probably a backslash issue

enkessler
2017-09-17 13:51:36

Record separators, line endings, and using OS specific command line tools instead of Ruby scripts are the most common reasons for breaks.

enkessler
2017-09-17 13:52:42

Gem
2017-09-19 15:06:33

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-19 15:06:39

Why would you need any special scenario outline support?

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-19 15:08:01

Scenario outlines get the example table values inlined before the match against the expression, so the type info would go in the expression, not the table.

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-19 15:08:34

OTOH, it would be nice to have it for data tables.

Gem
2017-09-19 15:08:41

Yeaaaaah...

Gem
2017-09-19 15:08:55

retreats to the corner

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-19 15:10:03

A way to declare a type for a column, for example:

| {age:int} | {name:word} |
| 2         |     joe     |
| 7         |     eva     |
👍 Gem
Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-19 15:13:54

Or even this, to get a list of Person objects (as you can do in Cucumber-JVM without any type info in the headers).

|       {person}          |
| {age:int} | {name:word} |
| 2         |     joe     |
| 7         |     eva     |
Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-19 15:14:55

Or is that too much "code" in the Gherkin?

Gem
2017-09-19 15:21:11

Could be.

Gem
2017-09-19 15:21:19

That's a battle I face a lot. 😕

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-19 15:22:32

It would be nicer to be able to declare a list type in the step definition:

# Data tables and doc strings **must** be captured with an output parameter - it's no longer implicit.
Given('the following {people} are registered') do |people|
end

I think that's genius if I say so myself.

Gem
2017-09-19 15:30:13

What would the feature file look like in that case?

Gem
2017-09-19 15:32:10

Gem
2017-09-19 15:32:23

Gem
2017-09-19 15:33:18

Gem
2017-09-19 15:33:21

Nice job!

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-19 15:42:49

Ah you're right, that doesn't work. How about this:

Given('the following people are registered:', Person) do |people|
end

And this Gherkin:

Given the following people are registered:
  | age       | name        |
  | 2         | joe         |
  | 7         | eva         |
💯 tooky

      [:step, :outline_step].each do |node_name|
        define_method(node_name) do |node|
          [-record_width_of_step-]{+record_width_of+} node
        end
      end

@@ -930,20 +930,11 @@ module Cucumber def of(node) # The length of the instantiated steps in --expand mode are currently # not included in the calculation of max => make sure to return >= 1 [-if node.respondto?(:name)-] [1, max - [-node.name.length-]{+node.tos.length+} - node.keyword.length].max[-else-] [- [1, max - node.text.length - node.keyword.length].max-] [- end-] end

      def record_width_of(node)
        @widths &lt;&lt; node.keyword.length + [-node.name.length + 1-]

[- end-] [- -] [- def recordwidthofstep(node)-] [- @widths << node.keyword.length + node.text.length-]{+node.tos.length+} + 1 end

      private

*Thread Reply:* ``` def of(node) # The length of the instantiated steps in --expand mode are currently # not included in the calculation of max => make sure to return >= 1 [1, max - node.to_s.length - node.keyword.length].max end

      def record_width_of(node)
        @widths &lt;&lt; node.keyword.length + node.to_s.length + 1
      end

```

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-27 12:51:31

Hi @matt-SmartBear I'm around

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-27 12:52:18

Hi @Aslak Hellesøy

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-27 12:52:52

I think I get what you were saying now - you didn’t want to issue a deprecation warning without also shipping the workaround in the same release, right?

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-27 12:53:06

Yes

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-27 12:53:42

A deprecation warning that cannot be addressed without upgrading again is annoying and pointless I think

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-27 12:54:32

It's ok to break backwards compatibility in a major release

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-27 12:55:33

It's nice to deprecate a disappearing feature before removing it, but it isn't always possible

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-27 12:55:45

Well, it's possible, just too much work

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-27 12:59:11

I’m thinking it’s maybe less annoying though to see a warning in a 2.99 release, and your choices are:

1) do the work and upgrade to 3.0.0 2) pin to 2.4

…versus upgrading and then having stuff break without any warning at all.

I think I’ve seen other projects do this, but I might be wrong.

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-27 12:59:53

So people wouldn't actually be using 2.99?

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-27 13:01:18

Do you think people will upgrade to a new major version, not read the release notes and expect no breaking changes?

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-27 13:03:13

If you think 2.99 with an unfixable deprecation is the way to go, go ahead and do it - I won't stop you.

olleolleolle
2017-09-27 13:03:33

Travis: I want to make a tiny change (Travis: skip gem update --system; rvm does it now on its own) - can I make this change on master? Or would you like a PR?

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-27 13:05:40

@Aslak Hellesøy I dunno. I think people will upgrade to the new major version and only go and read the release notes when something breaks 😄

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-27 13:06:29

cool, I just wanted to make sure I understood where you were coming from

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-09-27 13:07:04

I've never come across a project that does what you're suggesting. It could be an interesting experiment 😉

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-27 13:10:14

I think I got the idea from http://rspec.info/upgrading-from-rspec-2/

matt-SmartBear
2017-09-27 13:10:18

mike_the_seventh

@miketheseventh has joined the channel

mike_the_seventh
2017-10-06 11:16:11

Hey guys/gals, @matt-SmartBear referred me here. I'm trying to find a way to queue up the specific Scenarios that match a given cucumber tag, such that I can store them in an array for iteration. The ultimate goal is to run independent docker run commands with a single declared Scenario (hence the iteration) to test just that scenario on the container.

mike_the_seventh
2017-10-06 11:16:54

I had a nasty shell script with sed/awk/grep, but matt suggested I pose the question here to see if anyone had used the Gherkin parser to this exact end

mike_the_seventh
2017-10-06 11:18:26

before i go farther: does the problem statement make sense?

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-10-06 12:27:29

2017-10-06 12:28:52

mike_the_seventh
2017-10-06 12:29:52

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-10-09 03:51:34

Cucumber-Ruby currently has a Travis build (slow) and a CircleCI build (fast). The Travis build is complaining a lot about rubocop violations (double/single quotes). I find that rather distracting and I suggest retiring the Travis build for the cucumber-ruby repo.

matt-SmartBear
2017-10-10 12:15:44

*Thread Reply:* I’m all in favour of removing the travis build as long as the circle one gives us equivalent coverage @Aslak Hellesøy

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-10-10 14:39:36

enkessler

enkessler

enkessler
2017-10-19 16:37:59

Aslak Hellesøy
2017-10-20 01:44:30

No rebasing please. The rationale is well described here: https://medium.com/bekk/why-you-should-stop-using-git-rebase-5552bee4fed1 Just follow the command line guidelines in the PR

Medium
Why you should stop using Git rebase – Bekk – Medium
You love rebasing, right? Rewriting history might be appealing, but there are good reasons not to.
Reading time
7 min read
brasmusson
2017-10-20 09:24:29

I think the "No rebasing please" and the link is a bit simplified. There are actually two questions here that need to be discussed:

  1. How to merge a pull-request?
  2. How to make a pull-request branch mergeable (without merging it)? Github supply three ways to merge a pull-request (with buttons on the web page):
  3. Create a merge commit
  4. Squash and merge
  5. Rebase and merge My preferences is to never use "3. Rebase and merge", which the "Why you should stop using Git rebase" link also says. However, I do not agree that we should stop using Git rebase. When i comes to question 2 "How to make a pull-request branch mergeabe (without merging it)", I'm with @paoloambrosio (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-cpp/pull/129#issuecomment-336507953) and think that rebase is the way to do it. My experience with GitHub is that it does not display the pull-request diff correctly when merging from master to a pull-request branch, and don't think the "ladder type" Git history tree is a good thing. My preferences is also: to rebase pull-request branches before merging them (with a merge commit) when they were branched from master many commit down the history (creating bow-shaped branches: http://pdh11.blogspot.se/2013/06/bow-shaped-branches-git-workflow.html) to squash the commits on the pull-request branches when they are many and not logically separated, but rather a result of the accidental history (with some reference to the Panas and Clement paper "A Rational Design Process: How and Why to Fake It")
GitHub
cucumber-cpp support for cgreen test framework. by snewt · Pull Request #129 · cucumber/cucumber-cpp
As a user I want to use cgreen as an alternative test framework to gtest and boost in order to test native C complete with mocking capability. cucumber-cpp now recognizes and harnesses cgreen as a ...
pdh11.blogspot.se
Bow-shaped branches: a Git workflow
Distributed version control systems, and Git in particular, have for all practical purposes wiped out CVS, Subversion and similar systems. ...
enkessler
2017-10-20 19:24:51

@Aslak Hellesøy @brasmusson @matt-SmartBear Gymnasium was happy to inform me that my projects are out of date because gherkin 5.x is now a thing and so, in due course, I found the pickling conversation in #249. I have added my thoughts.

If I end up swaying anyone's opinions again like I did when gherkin 3.x came out, remember: it's not that I want to keep causing you all to do a major release right after a major release, it's that I just hate odd numbers. 😉

:nyanparrot: Gem
enkessler
2017-10-23 09:18:21

Remind me why the pass/fail status of a scenario is not part of the result but rather must be inferred from the status of the scenario's steps?

enkessler
2017-10-23 09:23:44

In particular, I am referring to the JSON output format.

brasmusson
2017-10-23 10:00:46

Because it was so in the Json produced by the Json Formatter of Cucumber-JVM v1.x. And because the Json output was and still is pretty much feature file oriented and not test case oriented. And because having the test case result represented as a first class thing is comparably new (Cucumber-Ruby v2, Cucumber-JVM v2).

enkessler
2017-10-23 10:14:36

Oh. So we just haven't gotten around to it yet? It's not because we specifically wanted it to not be there?

enkessler
2017-10-23 10:27:20

FYI: my motivation is a gem (https://github.com/rajatthareja/ReportBuilder )that combines many Cucumber JSON reports (such as might be generated from parallelized test suite across many machines) but those reports are all that it has to go on. So unlike the normal rerun formatter that can include or not a test failure due to an undefined step, this gem doesn't know if the user passed in --strict or not.

brasmusson
2017-10-23 11:22:09

a) Since the Json reports are processed by several third party tools (which can use reports from both Cucumber-Ruby and Cucumber-JVM) changes to the Json formatter output should be done with care. b) There are two different ideas for the future of the Json formatter output, one is to make the report properly test case oriented (and not include distracting detail from the feature file), and the other to make the generated Json report the list of event (serialized to Json) of the test case execution (like the gherkin library generates source, gherkin_document, pickles events in Json format)

enkessler
2017-10-23 12:15:01

Adding an overall test status to the JSON output would be an additive change. I'd like to think that wouldn't be too impacting. Receiving JSON serialized events would also work, because I assume that a 'failure' event would be emitted at some point for the test.

tooky
2017-10-25 05:10:24

To add fuel, the JVM / Ruby / JS json format outputs are all slightly different. The next version of any / all of them would be better conforming to a common schema.

👍 Gem
enkessler
2017-10-25 06:20:42

Yeah, if we could have a common format, that would be great.

👍 Gem

Gem
2018-01-18 23:04:12

@olleolleolle thanks for the 👍 ! Have any idea how to handle the error above?

luke
2018-01-19 01:36:12

The above error means someone else has pushed to your remote branch.

luke
2018-01-19 01:36:47

so the number of commits on your remote does not equal your local. You can do a git push -f

If you've done a git commit --amend or an interactive rebase the above happens.

Gem
2018-01-19 08:02:18

Ah, that makes sense. Thanks! I'll fix later

brasmusson
2018-01-22 08:57:57

The first JRuby build that did fail was #759 (https://circleci.com/gh/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/759), the failure came at the "install dependencies" stage and the error message is "Your bundle is locked to publicsuffix (3.0.1), but that version could not be found in any of the sources listed in your Gemfile". The Gemfile.lock (and Gemfile) in the commit of that build is exactly the same as in the previous successful JRuby build #755 (https://circleci.com/gh/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/755). So what happened? Could it be that it was just a glitch in CircleCI or something that caused the gem publicsuffix v3.0.1 to not be found? or has that gem version really been removed (in the 24h hours or so between #755 and #759)? I cannot say without further investigation. Which brings me to the extremely annoying fact that I cannot restart a job on CircleCI, has we still used TravisCI, that would be the first I would do (to see if the install error was a temporary glitch). However, from looking at the first failed JRuby build, there is not any indication that it was caused by a problem in Cucumber-Ruby (Ruby) code. So based on that information we should first investigate how to fix the Gemfile.lock, rather than to search for a Ruby code change that caused this.

circleci.com
Continuous Integration and Deployment
Hosted Continuous Integration for web applications. Set up your application for testing in one click, on the fastest testing platform on the internet.
brasmusson
2018-01-22 09:02:52

As public_suffix v3.0.1 exist according to <a href="http://rubygems.org">rubygems.org</a> (https://rubygems.org/gems/public_suffix), it looks even more likely that the error in build #759 was caused by a glitch in CircleCI.

brasmusson
2018-01-22 09:05:13

Which makes it sooo annoying that the "Rerun job with ssh" button on CircleCI says "you need write permissions to trigger builds".

2018-01-22 09:07:36

brasmusson
2018-01-22 09:38:20

That tells us that StringIO behaves differently on JRuby and the other Rubies, #1244 is all about changing from an array of strings to StringIO to handle mixed output with different encodings.

👍 Gem
enkessler
2018-01-22 09:39:53

JRuby - 100% compatible with Ruby except for when it's not.

😅 Gem
Gem
2018-01-22 10:09:35

Might it be something along the lines of what happened here? https://github.com/jruby/jruby/issues/2863

GitHub
UTF-16LE Regexp not working as expected · Issue #2863 · jruby/jruby
brasmusson
2018-01-22 10:31:29

It is the failing test of #1244 that is failing on JRuby, so #1244 solves the problem it intended to solve everywhere except on JRuby. Since that actual fix (using StringIO instead of an array of strings to intercept stdout) not seems worse in any way, we could move that test from the junit_spec.rb to junit_formatter.feature and tag it @wip-jruby to get back to green. And then investigate how to handle mixed encoding output also on JRuby as a separate task.

Gem
2018-01-22 10:32:29

👍

Gem
2018-01-26 20:27:17

Okay. So. The Windows build is all sorts of messed up. There's what seems to be a pretty common issue finding expected files (may be easy-ish to sort out depending on the cause) but there's another, more complicated issue I think.

It seems like scenarios, or the files they create, are bleeding into other scenarios and causing them to fail.

Gem
2018-01-26 20:32:11

I've spent a good amount of time going through scenarios marked todo-windows and running them to see what works/doesn't.

Gem
2018-01-26 20:33:04

Unfortunately, things that pass on their own may not when one or more other scenarios from the same file are run OR scenarios from other features are. On top of that, some situations can cause the amount of scenarios that fail to differ.

Gem
2018-01-26 20:33:12

For instance: bundle exec cucumber --profile windows_mri --order random features\docs\defining_steps\

Gem
2018-01-26 20:34:10

On multiple, back to back runs, I could see 8 failures, then 7, then 9, then 8, and then 10.

Gem
2018-01-26 20:37:04

On the last run of 10 failures, here's what failed:

skip_scenario.feature:3
nested_steps.feature:15
nested_steps_with_second_arg.feature:37
nested_steps_i18n.feature:17
nested_steps.feature:34
nested_steps.feature:80
nested_steps_with_second_arg.feature:9
ambiguous_steps.feature:55
nested_steps.feature:51
Gem
2018-01-26 20:37:35

In running each of those scenarios individually, ever single one passed.

Gem
2018-01-26 20:38:22

If I do: bundle exec cucumber -p windows_mri features/docs/defining_steps/skip_scenario.feature:3 features/docs/defining_steps/nested_steps.feature:15 the second scenario fails.

Gem
2018-01-26 20:38:56

If I switch their places, the latter scenario again fails

Gem
2018-01-29 07:44:41

Seems to be tied more tied to aruba given its the one running things. I've done some work on it but will need to do more.

matt-SmartBear
2018-02-01 10:28:59

Yeah it sounds like it’s in Aruba. It should be relativity easy to add a crude Before hook in our own test suite to tidy up any mess though, and test your theory @js?

Gem
2018-02-01 10:35:41

Heya @matt-SmartBear! Thanks for the follow up there! The before hook actually sounds like a really good idea.

I've been spending time working on getting through Windows hurdles and at the same time getting more familiar with how things work (though there's still miles of functionality to learn) so eventually I hope to get it. 🙂

My most recent work is trying to get cucumber-ruby using aruba 0.14.3 as it's currently using 0.6.1 which is from Aug 2014. If my research proves correct, there were some Windows issues solved in that time which would help me out. 🙂

Aslak Hellesøy
2018-05-18 02:34:07

@Gem I see there is a lot of formatting-related entries in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md. Let’s keep this out of the changelog as it doesn’t affect users. The changelog is for documenting changed behaviour - users don’t care how our source code is formatted, it just makes it hard to digest the changelog.

GitHub
cucumber/cucumber-ruby
cucumber-ruby - Cucumber for Ruby
Original URL: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md
Aslak Hellesøy
2018-05-18 02:35:03

Also - no need to do pull requests and branches for formatting changes - just push to master. Use https://trunkbaseddevelopment.com/

trunkbaseddevelopment.com
Trunk Based Development
A portal on this practice
Original URL: https://trunkbaseddevelopment.com/
👍 Gem

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1307

olleolleolle (https://github.com/olleolleolle)
#1307 CircleCI: use jruby-9.2.0.0
<p>This PR replaces the non-existent 9.1.16.0 image with the latest 9.2.0.0<br /> one.</p> <p>This only makes the tests <strong>run</strong>, it does not repair them.</p> <p><strong>Motivation</strong></p> <p>I found out that the jruby build failed due to a missing image.</p> <p><strong>Background</strong></p> <p>CircleCI throws away some older images when they're superseded by newer<br /> ones. The latest GA version of JRuby is now 9.2.0.0.</p> <p><strong>How has this been tested?</strong></p> <p>I'll let the CI run.</p> <p><strong>Steps</strong></p> <p>☐ Refactor (code change that does not change external functionality) ☑︎ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) ☐ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ☐ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)</p> <p><strong>What I did</strong></p> <p>☐ I've added tests for my code ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p>
Assignees
olleolleolle

brasmusson
2018-07-13 02:21:36

Now I have versions of Cucucmber-Ruby, Cucucmber-Ruby-Core and Cucumber-Ruby-Wire that uses the Gherkin compiler and Pickles. As these changes depend on step 1 (rewrite the Pretty formatter, remove the Legacy Api and the HTML formatter), so I intend to:

  1. release any unreleased on master
  2. merge step 1 (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/155, https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1305, https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1306 and https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1230) - which means that the next release will be a major version release
  3. create PR:s for use the Gherkin compiler and pickles
luke
2018-07-13 02:28:10

so is this the first / interim step in moving cucumber over to using the go engine?

brasmusson
2018-07-13 04:33:29

It is both prerequisite work for moving to use Gherkin v6 (with the Rule keyword and Go-gherkin-binary) and to use the go Cucumber-enginge, and it is also valuable improvements in their on right (for instance the removal of the Legacy Api is long overdue).

👍 Gem, tooky
luke
2018-07-13 04:36:39

👍 awesome stuff.

matt-SmartBear
2018-07-13 06:19:01

bloody awesome work @brasmusson!

matt-SmartBear
2018-07-13 06:19:09

do you want these reviewed or are you happy with them?

matt-SmartBear
2018-07-13 06:19:29

I’m about to go on vacation next week and I only have about half an hour before my wife comes home!

brasmusson
2018-07-13 06:23:54

I do not think a review is necessary before merging step 1 - but would be nice, of course. I'm more interested in get reviews of step 2 (using the Gherkin compiler and Pickles) - which will not be up on github until step 1 is merged. My hope is to get this done before end of Monday (when I will be away for the rest of the week) - which leaves today and Monday to get it done.

brasmusson
2018-07-13 06:29:34

> Now, the tests are running, but have a few failures.

The surfaced JRuby failures seems to come down to:

  1. "0.002503" is rounded to "0.002" on JRuby but to "0.003" on the other Rubies
  2. for a step definition like:
  Given(/&lt;...&gt;/) do
     ...
  end

Jruby will use the line of the "end" keyword as the line of the step definition, whereas the other Rubies will use the line of the "Given" keyword.

Hmm, didn't someone say "JRuby 100% Ruby - except when it isn't"?

😅 Gem
brasmusson
2018-07-13 11:31:07

Now the gems cucumber v3.1.2 and cucumber-core v3.2.0 are released. On Monday I intend to:

  1. merge the step 1 PR:s (#1305, #1306 and #1230 of Cucumber-Ruby)
  2. create PR:s for step 2 (the code is already available no GitHub - on the branches use-pickles - but I want to write proper commit messages, and write the appropriate PR descriptions of such substantial changes)

nodo (https://github.com/nodo)
#1021 Fix style violations
<p>At the moment, the codebase has several style violations. It would be great to refactor the code, such that we are up to date with the community best practices <a href="https://github.com/bbatsov/ruby-style-guide">https://github.com/bbatsov/ruby-style-guide</a>.</p> <p>The list of the violations is in two files:</p> <p>• <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/.rubocop_todo.yml">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/.rubocop_todo.yml</a> (auto generated) • <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/.rubocop.yml">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/.rubocop.yml</a></p> <p>These files specify the ignored violations. It would be great to remove some of the violations from the files and fix them progressively in order to keep the PRs small.</p>

Regex #match? infact in general a LOT of regex matching methods came in ruby 2.4

Gem
2018-07-30 10:51:06

Gem
2018-07-30 10:51:13

2018-07-30 10:55:33

Mike
2018-07-30 16:47:18

@Mike has joined the channel

luke
2018-07-31 00:07:02

@Gem for .match? if you use .match and your matchdata only has 1 item, you haven't strictly matched it.

So you could define a .match? method something like

def match?(arg)
  arg.match.length != 1
end
luke
2018-07-31 00:07:19

and if you wanted it inline you'd just extend String.

luke
2018-07-31 00:07:39
 
class String
  def match?
    self.match.length != 1
  end
end
Gem
2018-07-31 08:00:55

Good call @luke thanks!

brasmusson
2018-07-31 12:11:10

Since String#match exists already in Ruby v2.2 is can be used instead. match(&lt;x&gt;).nil? is the inverse of match?(&lt;x&gt;), I have fixed this on master

Gem
2018-07-31 14:14:31

Hey, thanks @brasmusson!

Gem
2018-08-04 20:37:13

Gem
2018-08-04 20:37:43

Gem
2018-08-04 21:16:47

Gherkin Ruby's gemspec has a ruby version of &gt;= 1.9.3 but cucumber-ruby's is 2.2

Aslak Hellesøy
2018-08-05 01:09:38

*Thread Reply:* Let’s bump them all to 2.2 or greater!

👍 Gem
Gem
2018-08-05 10:21:20

*Thread Reply:* Do we have any rules around when we deprecate older versions?

Aslak Hellesøy
2018-08-05 13:30:44

*Thread Reply:* Whenever the tests are no longer passing on that version, it’s cumbersome to make it pass, and the version is no longer supported, or hasn’t had a release in 5 years.

Aslak Hellesøy
2018-08-05 13:31:42

*Thread Reply:* I just made all of this up, we don’t have any rules. But that’s the rough heuristic I’ve been using.

Gem
2018-08-05 16:16:09

*Thread Reply:* That's fair enough!

Mike
2018-08-06 07:48:33

*Thread Reply:* yeah 1.9.3 and 2.1.X are no longer supported

👍 Gem
matt-SmartBear
2018-08-13 13:30:15

*Thread Reply:* We’ve tended to pull them when the Ruby version itself is unsupported and there’s any pain in maintaining compatibility.

Gem
2018-08-04 21:16:54

Are we keeping Gherkin that low?

Jarek
2018-08-10 04:26:54

Sirani McNeill
2018-08-14 02:56:03

Gem
2018-09-06 15:09:18

@Jarek the cucumber.yml is a configuration file for Cucumber tuning, not just for the repos specs. In this case though, it sounds like the specs are referring to the yml which seems fair enough to me.

Gem
2018-09-06 15:09:35

2018-09-06 15:09:39

Aslak Hellesøy
2018-09-23 23:25:48

I released gherkin v6 yesterday and broke cucumber-ruby because it appears to have a &gt;= dependency on gherkin. We should never use that relaxed dependencies.

majormoses (https://github.com/majormoses)
#160 `gherkin/parser` seems to be missing
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>It looks like the <code>gherkin</code> parser was moved from a standalone gem to something in <code>cucumber</code> mono repo but looks like something may not have been updated properly.</p> <pre><code>/home/travis/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.3.7/gems/cucumber-core-3.2.0/lib/cucumber/core/gherkin/parser.rb:2:in `require': cannot load such file -- gherkin/parser (LoadError) from /home/travis/.rvm/gems/ruby-2.3.7/gems/cucumber-core-3.2.0/lib/cucumber/core/gherkin/parser.rb:2:in `&amp;lt;top (required)&amp;gt;' from brasmusson
2018-09-24 03:58:55

> I released gherkin v6 yesterday

Great. Then I think we should release Cucumber-Ruby v4.0.0. So far the delta from v3.1.2 has been internal improvement (like using Pickles), but with Gherkin v6 there is a benefit also for the user. I'm ok with that Cucumber-Ruby v4 does not have an html formatter (until there is a standalone Go one), and that the internal feature file oriented formatters like the pretty formatter, does not handle the Rule keywork perfectly (but why invest in a ruby formatter when the plan is to more to standalone Go formatters), see https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/e99c1526bccea866547bf85482ca78eb7bef62fa/spec/cucumber/formatter/pretty_spec.rb#L459-L495. I'd like to look into releasing the coming weekend.

spec/cucumber/formatter/pretty_spec.rb:459-495
<pre><code> describe 'with the rule keyword' do define_feature &amp;lt;&amp;lt;-FEATURE Feature: Some rules Background: FB Given fb Rule: A The rule A description Background: AB Given ab Example: Example A Given a Rule: B The rule B description Example: Example B Given b FEATURE it 'ignores the rule keyword' do expect(@out.string).to include &amp;lt;&amp;lt;OUTPUT Feature: Some rules Background: FB Given fb Given ab Example: Example A Given a Example: Example B Given b OUTPUT </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

@Aslak Hellesøy Yes, but as far as I can see c21e is not released so the gem Gherkin v6.0.10 cannot be used directly ("cannot load such file -- c21e/exe_file" occurs without c21e in the bundle). The need to c21e is also mentioned in a TODO in the gemspec; https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/ruby/gherkin.gemspec#L14

gherkin/ruby/gherkin.gemspec:14
<pre><code> # TODO: Add dependency on c21e before making a release </code></pre>

Aslak Hellesøy
2018-11-08 07:36:25

The big sticker is gherkin 6. We should be prepared that the go executable might cause some issues. Ref https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/425#issuecomment-435323324

SabotageAndi (https://github.com/SabotageAndi)
Comment on #425 Gherkin: Delegate to Gherkin-Go prebuilt binaries
<p><a href="https://github.com/aslakhellesoy">@aslakhellesoy</a> We moved some parts of our Visual Extension into a separate process. And this didn't go well. So I have not really a desire to repeat that all with a central part like the Gherkin parser. And they will hit us on .NET again with this approach.</p> <p>The Problems were:</p> <p>• Encoding Problems with StdIn/StdOut. Some customers reported problems with special chars (<a href="https://github.com/techtalk/SpecFlow/issues/1215">techtalk/SpecFlow#1215</a>, <a href="https://github.com/techtalk/SpecFlow/issues/1205">techtalk/SpecFlow#1205</a>). I had to switch to transferring the data via files, because I couldn't get the Console correct configured. Which isn't nice either. • At least one of our customers uses a white list of allowed processes to be executed. The go- binaries as our Extension files will be in a folder that is not enabled to execute everything. So the gherkin parser would suddenly not work for them anymore. And I am sure, this is not the only customer of us who has this strict security settings.</p> <p>Additionally I see following problems:</p> <p>• We need the Gherkin parser not as .NET Core library, but as .NET Standard 2.0 library. .NET Standard is like the API levels of Android. .NET Core, .NET Framework, Xamarin (Android and iOS) and UWP are implementing this standard. The Gherkin parser has to work for all these implementations. With Xamarin and UWP you can run your tests on a device or emulator. I am not sure about if Android or iOS can execute the go-binaries, but UWP can't break out of is sandbox and execute some binary. • We use more and more the Gherkin parser at runtime also. So an output of a test project has to include these 15 files also. I think this is confusing our users, because they are not used to have dependencies as exes in their output. • Increased file size of library. The go- binaries are together 77MB. The current parser has 130kb. We will go from 130kb to 77MB in file size. How .NET packaging works, we have to put them into the NuGet package and put them into the output directories. • OS detection isn't something .NET is good at it, because we normally don't care on which OS we are running. We can probably differ between Windows, Mac and Linux, but not more via APIs. We would have to fallback to probing for the OS.</p> <p>These are my biggest problems I see when we would use this approach for .NET.<br /> Sorry that I didn't said something about my concerns earlier, but I didn't understood that this will be mandatory for all Gherkin parser and all other will be removed. I thought we could simply stick to the current way for the .NET parser.</p> <p>Like <a href="https://github.com/gasparnagy">@gasparnagy</a>, I would like to have the Gherkin parser for .NET under the cucumber umbrella. I have no preference if it's in a <code>cucumber/gherkin-dotnet-native</code> or the current <code>gherkin-dotnet</code> repo, but it should be in the cucumber organisation. We could also remove it from the monorepo and work in the separate repo alone. This would have the benefit to don't need the Makefile- build- process anymore and go to .NET standard tools. This would make the library more accessible for contributors that only know .NET.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>
Aslak Hellesøy
2018-11-08 07:36:54

We’ll see...

enkessler
2018-11-08 09:06:12

I think we still need that one architecture detecting patch to make things work on Windows.

Dana Scheider (they/he)
2018-11-08 14:01:20

@brasmusson I think we were hoping to get #1326 into the 4.0 release: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1326

danascheider (https://github.com/danascheider)
#1326 [DO NOT MERGE] Update code to include env files in dry run
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Causes Cucumber to load <code>env.rb</code> files even on dry run.</p> <p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>This PR removes a conditional in <code>configuration.rb</code> that prevents env files from loading when the <code>--dry-run</code> option is turned on. It also updates the help message for <code>--dry-run</code> to omit the part about env files not loading.</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p>In <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1324">#1324</a>, <a href="https://github.com/dpsi">@dpsi</a> brings up an issue they're having loading constants and libraries when Cucumber runs under the <code>--dry-run</code> option, pointing out that this is <a href="https://groups.google.com/d/msg/cukes/Kucz1T_VBss/VkEUBpY6MQAJ">not the first time</a> users have brought up this problem with us. The issue stems from the <code>env.rb</code> files not being loaded.</p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>The test ensuring that env files are not loaded on dry runs has been removed. I've ensured that env files do still load first in all cases.</p> <p><strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>☐ Refactor (code change that does not change external functionality) ☐ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) ☐ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ☐ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☐ I've added tests for my code ☑︎ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☑︎ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p>
Assignees
danascheider
Labels
status: work in progress (WIP)
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
Dana Scheider (they/he)
2018-11-08 14:01:32

Aslak gave it the thumbs up so I'm merging it and the corresponding docs PR now.

Dana Scheider (they/he)
2018-11-26 13:32:44

This issue report just got created and I wasn't sure how we wanted to handle it since I know we've made some changes to how scenario outlines work. I've labelled it as a bug since we said in a previous issue report that Cucumber supports examples in scenario outline titles, but I'm not sure how it fits in with recent changes. https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1328

Githraine (https://github.com/Githraine)
#1328 Scenario outlines still don't support examples in title
<p>We finally got upgraded to the latest Cuke.<br /> This is NOT resolved. Given this scenario outline:<br /> @mm<em>calc</em>tvr_001 <a href="https://github.com/wip">@wip</a><br /> Scenario Outline: Traditional vs Roth Base tests - &lt;title&gt;<br /> Given I output "&lt;title&gt;"<br /> And I am on the "Traditional vs Roth Calculator" calculator page<br /> When I populate the calculator from "" and "calculate"<br /> Then the calculator results should match the "base" section of ""</p> <pre><code>Examples: | title | inputs | | Single Higher Roth Now Matches | single_higher_now_roth_matches | | Married Higher Roth Now Matches | married_higher_now_roth_matches | | Married Lower Roth Now Matches | married_lower_now_roth_matches | | Married Lower Roth Later Matches | married_lower_later_roth_matches | | Married Lower 401k Later Matches | married_lower_later_401k_matches | | Single Lower Roth Later Matches | single_lower_later_roth_matches | | Married Lower 401k Later no Match | married_lower_later_401k_does_not_match | | Single Lower Later 401k no match | single_lower_later_401k_does_not_match | </code></pre> <p>the results are showing:<br /> Feature: Calculators - Traditional Vs Roth, Scenario: Traditional vs Roth Base tests - &lt;title&gt;, Examples (<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1">#1</a>)</p> <p><em>Originally posted by <a href="https://github.com/Githraine">@Githraine</a> in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/984#issuecomment-439983638">#984 (comment)</a></em></p>

Dana Scheider (they/he)
2018-11-26 15:43:38

Sounds good. I'll just clarify with the person who made the issue report specifically what they're asking for to begin with. @brasmusson had earlier suggested that what I think is being proposed might not be possible because of the Gherkin parser, but then he made the PR that supposedly fixed the behaviour. So to begin with I'll just clarify what's being asked for and go from there.

brasmusson
2018-11-27 04:13:24

Yes, the Gherkin compiler performs placeholder expansion in the name/title of the Scenario/Scenario Outline, so the Pickle name/title will have the placeholder replaces with data from the examples table. In any of the formatters that are Test Case oriented (for instance the JUnit formatter) that is also what must be included in the report. With respect to feature file oriented formatters (for instance the Pretty formatter) things are a bit more complicated, since in the feature file the Scenario/Scenario Outline does have placeholders in the name/title which therefore (naturally) is included in the report. With the use of the -x/--expand options the Pretty formatter does expand the Scenario/Scenario Outline with examples data in the report, which then means that the placeholders should be expanded.

With respect to the reported issue I see two problems, a) I did not find any information of the Cucumber-Ruby version used (the fix is not included until v4.0.0.rc1), and b) I do not see en example of the output/data claimed to be wrong, "it does not work" is a bit vague (which Slackbot soon will tell us).

👍 Gem, Dana Scheider (they/he)
Gem
2018-11-27 08:35:47

haha, It didn't. 😛 It may look for the contraction? It doesn't work

slackbot
2018-11-27 08:35:47

Hi, it's cukebot again. "Doesn't work" is rather vague. What are you seeing and what had you expected to see?

Gem
2018-11-27 08:35:56

There we go 😉

Gem
2018-11-27 08:37:31

2019-08-27 08:23:59

2019-08-27 08:24:41

2019-08-27 08:38:44

Had a maybe eureka moment leaving work. Processes??

luke
2019-08-27 08:39:38

Process 1 - run ruby. Frozen string true Process 2 - run Aruba to run the command which will write these files (no frOzen strong)

Puts runs in p1?

luke
2019-09-10 09:06:40

for other people ☝️ I was right. I'm gonna make the code uber - verbose and put a comment in saying we should probably look to refactor this methodology, as it plays havoc with IDE's and editors and would be the kind of thing in a strongly typed language that would probably fail to compile.

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 05:22:32

@luke I’m reading your (draft) post about the new only_load_files_once config option and I’m confused about a couple of things.

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 05:23:15

First big and dumb question is: when we talk about Cucumber reloading things (i.e. using load) that isn’t happening for every scenario, is it? Just when the process starts?

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 05:32:33

Other question is, why don’t we make require the default now, if we’re doing this in a major version? Seems like new users would fine require the least surprising behaviour, so we should make it the default.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-12 05:33:20

I think there was a discussion between require and load some 9-10 years ago - don’t remember the details…

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 05:34:07

Also, I don’t see details of your changes from https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1043 - except for your pleas from April for me to review your code - so sorry!

roberts1000 (https://github.com/roberts1000)
#1043 Use `require` to load support files instead of `load`
<p>I've run into a situation where I would like to control the load order for files in the <code>features/support</code> folder.</p> <p>I got the impression, from reading The Cucumber Book, that Cucumber would behave similar to RSpec and only autoload <code>features/support/</code>. I tried moving the files into <code>features/setup/</code> and manually requiring the files from <code>env.rb</code>. I quickly discovered that Cucumber wants to take over and load everything, regardless of the sub folder. (To be precise, RSpec doesn't autoload files in <code>spec/support</code> unless it's specifically configured to do so.)</p> <p>Next I tried moving all the files back into the <code>features/support</code> folder, but having File A explicitly require File B t to make sure File B is loaded before File A is executed. Unfortunately, this doesn't work either because Cucumber uses the <code>load</code> method to load the support files. <strong>Is there any reason Cucumber couldn't use <code>require</code> instead of <code>load</code> in this method?</strong></p> <p><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/lib/cucumber/rb_support/rb_language.rb#L107">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/lib/cucumber/rb<em>support/rb</em>language.rb#L107</a></p> <p>That would give us much more flexibility in controlling the order of how support files are loaded. <code>require</code> would guarantee the file is only loaded once. It wouldn't matter if Cucumber got to it first or I manually required it somewhere.</p> <p>As it stands now, my only options are to combine the two dependent files into a single file, OR, move files outside of the feature folders; neither of which are good options. The use of <code>load</code> blocks any attempt to establish order because it will blindly load the file even if it has already been loaded.</p>
Assignees
luke-hill
Labels
Slow Burner
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 05:43:11

Oh sorry, is it this PR? https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1349

luke-hill (https://github.com/luke-hill)
#1349 Spike/altered loading strategy
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Provide a way for cucumber to only load files once.</p> <p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>Using a config switch, decide on whether cucumber should recurse through files potentially <code>n</code> times, or just once only.</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p>This fixes an old problem here: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1043">#1043</a> - Where the user had procedural code which was being instantiated twice. A user should be able to specify the load order of a file, and "not" have the file loaded twice.</p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>Unit Tests have been added in the appropriate file.</p> <p><strong>Screenshots (if appropriate):</strong> <strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>☑︎ Refactor (code change that does not change external functionality) ☐ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) ☑︎ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ☐ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I've added tests for my code ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p> <p>Outstanding questions FYI: <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">@mattwynne</a> / <a href="https://github.com/roberts1000">@roberts1000</a></p> <p>• Should we use the top level config or the config level which requires flags. • How should we advertise this? • Is there anything missing?</p>
Labels
Slow Burner
Comments
8
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 05:43:23

When it said “Spike” in the title I assumed it was not for keeps

luke
2019-09-12 05:59:18

it was testing 2 different methodologies. One of which I removed half-way down the line.

luke
2019-09-12 05:59:48

as for making require the default, we can do. I just figured you'd want to deprecate it first, or maybe have some form of notice period for people.

luke
2019-09-12 06:00:51

Also: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1043#issuecomment-256893620

mattwynne (https://github.com/mattwynne)
Comment on #1043 Use `require` to load support files instead of `load`
<p>Thinking about this some more, I wonder if we could have two, configurable strategies, so the user can choose whether to use <code>load</code> or <code>require</code> during their test run. That would allow us to continue to use <code>load</code> in our own tests, but I'd have thought 80% of our regular users would be happy with <code>require</code>.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 09:15:40

Yeah so according to my past self, using require as the default strategy would be fine. I think I still agree with my past self 🙂

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 09:16:22

@luke I’m still confused about when the “reload” happens. It doesn’t reload support code files per scenario, does it?

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 09:16:41

it’s just that it might load the same support file twice if you’ve already explicitly required it?

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 09:37:57

I’m still puzzled by why we made it use load in the first place! Here’s the commit:

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/commit/e764295622144b4cab449e3e68615ab70c7491e7

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-12 09:38:58

Maybe it was something to do with Spork, which we used back in the day for optimizing Rails tests by re-running them in the same process?

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-12 10:22:57

Good find @matt-SmartBear - 9 years ago!

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-12 10:23:48

I wonder if we can find the original issue in what what is called - lighthouse?

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-12 16:08:57

Here: https://lighthouseapp.com

luke
2019-09-13 01:16:14

I found the PR's that altered it twice in 2010 / 2011, and all that was mentioned that was it was changed deliberately (And comments alongside it accordingly).

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-13 02:53:51

I’m pretty sure Lighthouse is not publishing pages from our issue tracker anymore.

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-13 02:58:36

I vaguely remember having a vision at the time that you could have one long-running Cucumber process that could keep running your test suite over and over as you worked. I’m pretty sure it must have had something to do with Spork as well, but anyway I think it’s a good idea to make require the default for a major release, and still offer people the option to use load if they really need it.

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-13 02:59:17

I did try an appeal on Twitter to ask for users who might be affected but no response yet: https://twitter.com/mattwynne/status/1172191404619116545

twitter
mattwynne (https://twitter.com/mattwynne/status/1172191404619116545)
Any Rails + Cucumber users who use Zeus or Spring or some other process pre-loader thingy? Would you be upset if we changed this? <https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1043>

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 02:59:32

I think you’re right @matt-SmartBear - require sounds like the right thing to do by default.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 05:17:04

@luke - since you’re about to cut a release of cucumber-rails I had a look at the changelog. I noticed you added a runtime dependency on aruba in the previous release. What was the motivation behind that?

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 05:17:57

Actually, that’s happened in the unreleased code, not the last release.

luke
2019-09-13 05:23:38

couple of small reasons, to help with some tests and a couple of use cases that people will be using going forwards. Plus a slight tweak to a new config option (Which is easiest to use with aruba)

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 05:24:49

I don’t understand why you think Cucumber-Rails needs a runtime dependency on Aruba. It doesn’t use it.

luke
2019-09-13 05:25:51

one of the new config switches I added would be easier to use with aruba. It isn't needed, but it's not not needed (so to speak). It makes things a bit easier for the consumer.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 05:26:31

What config switch? How does it become easier?

luke
2019-09-13 05:27:02

there is a new feature to allow the cucumber rails world to look different, and not have some of the rack inbuilt stuff

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 05:27:50

Yes I saw that. Still don’t understand why that needs a runtime dependency on Aruba.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 05:29:29

You’ve modified lib/cucumber/rails/world.rb to conditionally include a module based on the value of an environment variable. That code does not need Aruba to run.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 05:32:15

Dependencies that are only used by test code and not library code should never become runtime dependencies.

luke
2019-09-13 05:33:42

yes I know that. As I said, it was to make it easier for the consumers

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 05:34:07

What precisely becomes easier for consumers?

luke
2019-09-13 05:34:07

i'll just remove it to save the aggro.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 05:35:21

Do you think I am being aggressive? I am simply trying to understand your motivation. I still don’t understand what becomes easier.

luke
2019-09-13 05:37:38

When I was creating the PR, some of the people I spoke to who used it said they booted up rails in a way where they used aruba directly to assign ENV vars instead of on the cli like bundle exec {thing} VAR_ONE=val_1

luke
2019-09-13 05:38:10

they instead used aruba to assign those values directly. They can directly require and install aruba alongside it, so to answer your question it isn't "needed" as a direct dependency, so I can remove it.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-13 05:38:21

Thanks

luke
2019-09-16 02:47:27

Has something changed in either gherkin-ruby or something similarly ruby-ish. That could cause a large amount of failures?

luke
2019-09-16 02:47:58

in https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1349 I had one failing rspec test. I fixed it up and now get a whole heap of failures in the feature tests. It looks like aruba style failures in things like f.feature with annotations.

luke-hill (https://github.com/luke-hill)
#1349 Spike/altered loading strategy
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Provide a way for cucumber to only load files once.</p> <p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>Using a config switch, decide on whether cucumber should recurse through files potentially <code>n</code> times, or just once only.</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong></p> <p>This fixes an old problem here: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1043">#1043</a> - Where the user had procedural code which was being instantiated twice. A user should be able to specify the load order of a file, and "not" have the file loaded twice.</p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>Unit Tests have been added in the appropriate file.</p> <p><strong>Screenshots (if appropriate):</strong> <strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>☑︎ Refactor (code change that does not change external functionality) ☐ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) ☑︎ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ☐ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I've added tests for my code ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p> <p>Outstanding questions FYI: <a href="https://github.com/mattwynne">@mattwynne</a> / <a href="https://github.com/roberts1000">@roberts1000</a></p> <p>• Should we use the top level config or the config level which requires flags. • How should we advertise this? • Is there anything missing?</p>
