luke-hill (https://github.com/luke-hill)
#1351 Omit Appveyor runs whilst failures are investigated
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Disable Appveyor from running whilst it has large amounts of failures</p> <p><strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>☐ Refactor (code change that does not change external functionality) ☑︎ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) ☐ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ☐ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☐ I've added tests for my code ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p> <p>Related Links:<br /> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/916">#916</a> - Allow Windows Users to Develop<br /> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1116">#1116</a> - <a href="https://github.com/enkessler">@enkessler</a> adding AppVeyor / Updating Travis (June 2017)<br /> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1215">#1215</a> - Outstanding Issue to fix Windows builds <a href="https://github.com/jaysonesmith">@jaysonesmith</a> / <a href="https://github.com/bv">@bv</a> have done some investigation on this, I've done a little bit myself.</p>

2019-09-16 02:53:55

Continuous Integration and Deployment
Hosted Continuous Integration for web applications. Set up your application for testing in one click, on the fastest testing platform on the internet.
Original URL: https://circleci.com/gh/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/2690

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-16 03:15:08

@brasmusson sent a PR that resurrects the native Ruby Gherkin a couple of days ago. In case you’ve missed it - we’re abandoning the shell-out-to-go-executable approach for the time being.

luke
2019-09-16 04:10:50

☝️ wasn't that one of the key tenets of us migrating to the protobuf stuff

luke
2019-09-16 04:10:58

or have I done 2+2=5

brasmusson
2019-09-16 04:59:34

The PR in the mono-repo to resurrect the native gherkin-ruby parser, https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/pull/702, does not change the parser interface used by Cucumber-ruby, so it worked transparently with the current Cucumber-ruby master.

brasmusson (https://github.com/brasmusson)
#702 gherkin-ruby: Revert the native ruby parser for gherkin
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>• Revert the native ruby parser for gherkin.</p> <p><strong>Details</strong></p> <p>• Revert the native ruby parser for gherkin. • Updates due to a new version of cucumber-messages. • Populate the id attribute of pickles.</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong> <strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>Tested with the Gherkin acceptance test suite</p> <p><strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>☐ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue). ☑︎ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality). ☐ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected).</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☐ The change has been ported to Java. ☑︎ The change has been ported to Ruby. ☐ The change has been ported to JavaScript. ☐ The change has been ported to Go. ☐ The change has been ported to .NET. ☐ I've added tests for my code. ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p>
Labels
language: ruby, library: gherkin
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>
👏 matt-SmartBear
brasmusson
2019-09-16 05:07:31

The CI builds for Cucumber-ruby have been failing for appveyor and on JRuby for quite a while, but they pass on Ruby 2.3-2.6 (for instance for the latest commit on master).

luke
2019-09-16 05:47:47

yeh it's ok. It's my code that's the issue, however it was masked because of fail_fast.

luke
2019-09-16 05:48:14

I thought it all passed apart from one rspec failure. So when I fixed that and saw 20 new failures I thought something had gone wrong elsewhere.

luke
2019-09-17 01:48:46

good news @matt-SmartBear I know what the issue is. It's similar to the issues I found when making configs for aruba/cucumber rails.

luke
2019-09-17 01:49:22

Because all of our tests run in one thread and we repeatedly re-create the same file structure inside tmp/aruba the files need re-loading for each test. So essentially we need to use the config value (for the legacy autoloader)

luke
2019-09-17 01:50:09

Interestingly, for us to remove this config option we would need to go in and make sure each file had a unique support code and name (It's not a problem in itself, but it's something that would need doing)

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-17 03:34:02

Cool, so at least we have one use-case for the legacy auto-loader!

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-17 03:34:16

Well done for figuring it out @luke

🎉 Gem
luke
2019-09-17 03:34:23

haha yeh 😛

luke
2019-09-17 03:34:47

I've added a TODO in there though, because this would be something in theory that we may want to later alter. i.e. not have to run it in our testing aruba processes

luke
2019-09-17 03:35:14

because re-loading the files is fine, it's reloading the files which have an identical name which are wiped and then re-created that causes the issue

luke
2019-09-17 03:35:31

So I know for instance over half of the tests have duplication in file names.

matt-SmartBear
2019-09-17 03:37:01

Good call. If we made the steps more abstract (i.e. Given a step definition with as opposed to Given a file "steps.rb" with: then we’d have the flexibility to use unique generated file names.

luke
2019-09-17 04:41:26

ooooh, maybe using anonymous classes to generate a random file name?

Aslak Hellesøy

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-09-18 07:49:05

This article is less than 600 words: https://cucumber.io/blog/keep-your-scenarios-brief/ - less is more

Cucumber Blog
Keep your scenarios BRIEF
Over the years that we have been using Gherkin, our approach to writing scenarios has evolved. Because Gherkin is very close to natural language it's very easy to learn, but just like writing reports or stories, it takes practice to do it well. There are three main goals that we try to keep in mind when writing scenarios: * Scenarios should be thought of as documentation, rather than tests. * Scenarios should enable collaboration between business and delivery, not prevent it. * Scenarios
Written by
Seb Rose
Original URL: https://cucumber.io/blog/keep-your-scenarios-brief/

luke
2019-10-15 00:47:46

Hi @Aslak Hellesøy @XtraSimplicity tried to push cucumber rails 2 today but doesn't have privileges, only cukebot does now. Are you able to either push it or walk us through how to use it.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-10-15 00:54:34

Hi @luke @XtraSimplicity did you see the issue about release candidates? https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/734

aslakhellesoy (https://github.com/aslakhellesoy)
#734 Document how to coordinate releases
<p>Lots of other tools depend on Cucumber's APIs and outputs. While it's important to improve Cucumber, it is also important to reduce the amount of friction a new release causes for our users.</p> <p>We need to give tool vendors a chance to update their products to upcoming changes that break backwards compatibility. This is what I propose:</p> <p>• All major releases (incompatible API changes) MUST be preceded by at least one pre-release • At least 4 weeks MUST elapse between a major prerelease and a major release • APIs SHOULD be deprecated before being removed/changed in an incompatible manner • Deprecation notices SHOULD suggest what users can do to migrate to the new API</p> <p>This is not an exhaustive or final list - feedback is very welcome.</p>
Labels
type: build, type: docs
Comments
7
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>
luke
2019-10-15 00:55:52

maybe, let me re-check.

luke
2019-10-15 00:56:43

Rightio yeh. So this one is a bit tricky. The only major breaking bit was removing web_steps, which was already "kind of" removed by yourself.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-10-15 00:57:33

It’s a matter of principle. When we make a major release of something we have by definition broken backwards compatibility. When we do that we need community feedback before pulling the trigger.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-10-15 00:57:42

Regarding access to the cukebot credentials - it seems like 1Password is not a good solution since there is no free plan. @mpkorstanje and I did an experiment with https://keybase.io/ for sharing secrets, and I think that will work well as a replacement since it’s free.

keybase.io
Keybase
Keybase is for keeping everyone's chats and files safe, from families to communities to companies. MacOS, Windows, Linux, iPhone, and Android.
Original URL: https://keybase.io/

Vincent Pretre
2019-10-15 07:55:11

I’m giving a try to meta (https://github.com/mateodelnorte/meta) which should help manage common branches between the various Ruby related repositories (cucumber-ruby, cucumber-ruby-core, cucumber-ruby-wire). Not a real monorepo as cucumber/cucumber, more a manyrepo.

mateodelnorte/meta
<p>tool for turning many repos into a meta repo. why choose many repos or a monolithic repo, when you can have both with a meta repo?</p>
Stars

Language
<p>JavaScript</p>

Vincent Pretre
2019-10-29 05:43:51

Ok, bbut why is this feature passing on all Ruby versions ? - https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/gherkin-8/features/docs/gherkin/rule.feature - because we use another protobuf version ?

features/docs/gherkin/rule.feature
<pre><code>Feature: Rule After running an example mapping session, you end up with four kind of cards: features, rules, examples and questions. Since Gherkin 6, this is easily translated in your feature files. Background: Given a file named "features/rule.feature" with: """ Feature: Rule Sample Rule: This is a rule Example: First example Given some context When I do an action Then some results should be there Example: Second example Given some context When I do another action Then some other results should be there Rule: This is a second rule Example: First example Given some other context When I do another action Then some results should be there """ And a file named "features/step_definitions/steps.rb" with: """ Given("some context") { } Given("some other context") { } When("I do an action") { } Then("some results should be there") { } When("I do another action") { } Then("some other results should be there") { } """ Rule: I use Gherkin 6+ Example: I can use the Rule keyword When I run `cucumber -q features/rule.feature` Then it should pass with exactly: """ Feature: Rule Sample Example: First example Given some context When I do an action Then some results should be there Example: Second example Given some context When I do another action Then some other results should be there Example: First example Given some other context When I do another action Then some results should be there 3 scenarios (3 passed) 9 steps (9 passed) """ </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
Aslak Hellesøy
2019-10-29 05:44:33

Yes, probably because it’s using the protobuf version from the gemspec rather than overriding it in Gemfile

Vincent Pretre
2019-10-29 05:45:34

aslakhellesoy (https://github.com/aslakhellesoy)
#777 gherkin: Add acceptance test that fails on Ruby 2.4
<p>This fails on Ruby 2.4 because protobuf on that version does not allow setting <code>nil</code> fields.</p> <p>Two possible fixes:</p> <p>• Upgrade protobuf • Only set a rule's <code>description</code> if it's not <code>nil</code> in <code>ast_builder.rb</code> (we do this conditionally already for other elements)</p> <p>I'd love to make this fail in CI before fixing it though!</p>

language: ruby, library: gherkin, type: bug

Cucumber-Ruby 4.0.0.rc.3 is out. The new Rule keyword introduces closer resemblance with Example Mapping! <https://cucumber.io/blog/announcing-cucumber-ruby-4-0-0rc2/>

Twitter
Vincent Pretre
2019-10-31 05:09:14

funny thing in the blog post: the Markdown gherkin highlighter does not yet recognize Ruleand Example 😄

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-10-31 05:12:30

That’s one of the challenges with this grammar change. Lots of syntax highlighters out there must be updated.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-10-31 05:13:29

Hopefully the maintainers of these highlighters will pick it up, but we could help them by creating issues and/or PRs.

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-10-31 05:29:12

Created an issue here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/779

aslakhellesoy (https://github.com/aslakhellesoy)
#779 Update Gherkin syntax highlighters to support Rule keyword
<p>With the release of Gherkin 8 and Cucumbers using it, various syntax highlighters must be updated to support the new keywords.</p> <p>A good start is to create issues in these tools' bug trackers. The issues should suggest using <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/gherkin-languages.json">gherkin-languages.json</a> to do code-generation. That way the lexers/parsers can be easily updated when new translations are added (or if we make other grammar changes in the future).</p> <p>I have compiled a list of highlighters/editors below. Please add a comment with a link to the issue/PR if you create one and I will update this list. We'll check the box when an issue is fixed.</p> <p>☐ Ace ☐ CodeMirror ☐ Highlight.js ☐ IntelliJ IDEA ☐ Prism.js ☐ Pygments ☐ Rainbow ☐ Rainbow ☐ SHJS ☐ Source Highlight ☐ SyntaxHighlighter ☐ Vim ☐ Visual Studio Code ☐ Sublime Text ☐ TextMate</p> <p>Which ones did I forget?</p>
Labels
Slow Burner
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>

tooky
2019-11-21 03:43:29

@Aslak Hellesøy @Vincent Pretre I thought I’d fiddle a little with cucumber-ruby while I’m resting this morning. It looks like master is broken: https://circleci.com/gh/cucumber/workflows/cucumber-ruby/tree/master

It seems to be due to a change in the message protocol.

cucumber-ruby-core is expecting locations but it looks like it now needs to build those based on sourceIds

circleci.com
Continuous Integration and Deployment

Aslak Hellesøy
2019-11-21 03:47:45

@tooky this came up at today’s community meeting, and @Vincent Pretre has already submitted a PR for this: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core/pull/184

vincent-psarga (https://github.com/vincent-psarga)
#184 Force cucumber-message version to 6.x
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p>Until we can support <code>cucumber-messages</code> 7, we'll force the use of the 6.0 releases.</p> <p><strong>Motivation and Context</strong> <strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong> <strong>Screenshots (if appropriate):</strong> <strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>☐ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue) ☐ New feature (non-breaking change which adds functionality) ☐ Breaking change (fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected)</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☐ I've added tests for my code ☐ My change requires a change to the documentation. ☐ I have updated the documentation accordingly.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core">cucumber/cucumber-ruby-core</a>

Vincent Pretre
2020-01-06 02:25:32

@Aslak Hellesøy I'm being a bit lost / englued in my PR for the protobuf formater. I've tried to include way too much in the single PR which makes it unreadable and hard to understand. I think I'll try to break in into smaller PRs, each more focused on a single task. Basically, it would be something like this (in order, and starting from master of Cucumber): • Add a service for locating objects (Test::Case or Test::Step for example). Those objects will then be free of the Location objects and the service will be queried when we need to know where the object comes from • Add a service used to map objects from cucumber-core (Test::Case , Test::Step and Hook) and those from cucumber(like StepDefinitions and Hook ) - same principles as before, this service will ease decoupling (instead of adding references between the objects like I did previously) • Add the envelopeevent in the Bus and emit the correct messages • Add the message formatter (which will just listen to those messages and output them, json or bin) It may seem like a big waste of time of the last weeks but I should be able to reuse most of the work done there

matt-SmartBear
2020-01-07 03:33:42

luke
2020-01-07 03:44:30

Vincent Pretre

luke
2020-01-07 04:45:13

haha yeh sadly so. I just made a branch to use cucumber4 with cucumber rails and suffice it to say some stuff went ping. So I'll have fun digging into that soon I reckon.

brasmusson
2020-01-07 06:45:22

@Vincent Pretre TBH I have not looked on the cucumber-ruby/cucumber-ruby-core/gherkin code for a some (a long) time. However, in the spirit of getting up a characterization test for a message formatter ASAP, I would approach a message formatter as any formatter listening to the current events on the event bus, collecting data and the emitting the correct sequence of messages (in json - because bin is not readable). Several of the current formatters use cucumber::formatter::ast_lookup heavily to collect data from different previously received event bus messages, I recon that the message formatter will have to use it or something similar since AFAIK there is not simple mapping between the current event bus messages and the new intendened cucumber-messages messages.

> references between the objects like I did previously Object references are certanitly not the way to go, it was hard work to get away from the object references from the Test::Case and Test::Step object to the (old non-gherkin) AST-objects when moving from cucumber v3 to cucumber v4.

Vincent Pretre
2020-01-07 07:23:23

*Thread Reply:* yes, I discovered (a bit too late at my taste 😄 ) that the references were definitely not the way to go 😕

Vincent Pretre
2020-01-07 07:24:26

*Thread Reply:* for the message formatter, what it'll do is simply output anything sent though the envelope event on the bus. the output (binor ndjson ) will be decided based on user choice.

brasmusson
2020-01-07 10:45:21

*Thread Reply:* Saying the the message formatter is simply outputing anything sent through the 'envelope' event on the bus, is to include implementation details in the specification. Eventually that will be true, but it does imply the cucumber-ruby uses and cucumber-messages type event bus. To achieve the the specification that "When I run a feature file <like this>, the message formatter output <that> json output" does not require any 'envelope' events on the bus, just that the intended json output can be synthesized from the event stream that a formatter currently can listen to in cucumber-ruby. Then (after "make it work" is achieved), the focus could be turned to "make it right" which a recon means that the internal event model in cucumber-ruby is change to (solely) cucumber-messages type events.

👍 matt-SmartBear

2020-04-21 03:51:54

Hi folks, Can someone tell me where I can find a description of what ~&gt; means in the context of semver?

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-04-21 03:53:57

Consider this: s.add_dependency 'cucumber-messages', '~&gt; 12.0', '&gt;= 12.0.0' - will that install 12.1.0 ?

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-04-21 03:55:32

I answered by own question - yes it will

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-04-21 04:10:05

@Vincent Pretre I’ll prepare a PR for Cucumber-Ruby that emits a new Meta message (using cucumber-messages 12.1.0 )

Vincent Pretre
2020-04-21 04:13:11

cool 🙂

Vincent Pretre
2020-04-21 04:14:03

@Aslak Hellesøy - note that the CCK part of the CI is more than likely to fail as it point to a tag on the mono-repo

luke
2020-04-21 04:22:42

The only bit to bear in mind is ~&gt; n is essentially useless. It's a minor bug in the way gemfiles work, but it's not worth fixing because it's rarely used.

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-04-21 05:53:57

Am I correct that ~&gt; MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH will match any version with major == MAJOR &amp;&amp; minor &gt;= MINOR ? In that case I find it very useful, as it would allow for a floating dependency on any higher version that doesn’t break backwards compatibility according to semver.

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-04-21 07:27:04

*Thread Reply:* Found the spec for ~&gt; at https://guides.rubygems.org/patterns/#pessimistic-version-constraint. Why do you think it’s useless @luke?

guides.rubygems.org
Patterns - RubyGems Guides
Tutorials, guides, FAQs for RubyGems package management
Original URL: https://guides.rubygems.org/patterns/#pessimistic-version-constraint
luke
2020-04-21 08:00:44

*Thread Reply:* Later on in the article it mentions about being careful with it. But yeh, if you use ~&gt; n.0 it just removes ambiguity

enkessler

Annnnnd, never mind. Silly me was not looking at the most recent commit. 😅

enkessler
2020-05-11 03:57:59

You crazy lot are apparently up to 13 now. 😛

enkessler
2020-05-11 03:59:15

Related question: What's the reasoning behind increasing the version number of the gem if it's not released? 9 is the latest on that I see on rubygems.org.

enkessler
2020-05-11 04:10:44

Well, okay, technically they were released. I see the gem artifacts on GitHub. Are newer version going to be published to RubyGems as well or is GitHub where people will have to get them going forward?

Vincent Pretre
2020-05-11 04:46:47

The gem you're looking for is there: https://rubygems.org/gems/cucumber-gherkin

Vincent Pretre
2020-05-11 04:47:28

We've done some renaming to have more consistency across the various gems and languages (and also ease/automate release process)

Vincent Pretre
2020-05-11 04:48:22

So there will not be anymore gherkin gem, but there will be cucumber-gherkin releases instead

Vincent Pretre
2020-05-11 04:49:48

For the version number, most major bumps are due to major changes in cucumber-messages, not really huge changes in Gherkin itself.

enkessler
2020-05-11 10:52:48

*Thread Reply:* Are they at least breaking changes in the gherkin API?

Vincent Pretre
2020-05-12 00:30:53

*Thread Reply:* Not in the API itself (at least for Ruby, some changes where introduced in the JS version), but the produced messages are incompatible with previous versions.

enkessler
2020-05-12 23:32:21

*Thread Reply:* For the purposes of answering the question of "is this no longer backwards compatible?", that sounds like it still counts. Good to know.

enkessler
2020-05-30 04:30:52

*Thread Reply:* Fun fact: there are also breaking changes in the API, even within the same major version.

enkessler
2020-05-11 10:22:32

So this is what will finally make me stop being so backwards compatible and drop support for older versions of Ruby, eh? I'm pretty sure that I can't have my gem depend on both gherkin and cucumber-gherkin . Nor can I have it depend on neither of them. So a major version bump that switches from one to the other it is.

olleolleolle
2020-05-24 12:59:40

*Thread Reply:* Celebrate!

enkessler
2020-05-30 04:27:35

*Thread Reply:* Hey, it was a fun programming exercise to maintain a code library that had to work with Ruby 1.8.7 to the current version and with Gherkin 2.x to the current version on all 3 of the major OS platforms (Windows, Linux, and OSX). 😛

enkessler
2020-05-30 04:36:12

*Thread Reply:* It's also been an interesting glimpse into the minds of the maintainers because some of the changes that I have seen across versions and the cavalier pace at which new versions come out is, I suspect, in no small part due to the fact that, from their point of view, the gherkin/cucumber-gherkin gem is rarely directly consumed and so users are only really impacted by new major versions of the cucumber gem. In other words: that messing with the lower level gem only impacts the various Cucumber implementations, which are more or less maintained by the same people and therefore it's no big deal for them to incorporate the new stuff.

enkessler
2020-05-30 04:58:41

*Thread Reply:* Not that it's been challenging for me to handle the changes. They just seem a bit 'willy-nilly'.

"So I've got to use require 'gherkin'. Makes sense. Oh, now it's require 'gherkin/gherkin'. Whoops, it's back to require 'gherkin' now. I wonder what tomorrow will bring?"

or

"Hand the parsing mechanism some Gherkin text -> get a Gherkin document back. Now, hand the parsing mechanism some Gherkin text and explicitly tell it that you want a Gherkin document back-> get a Gherkin document back. Now-now, same as the previous version except you have get the document back using :gherkin_document instead of :gherkinDocument because this release was written by a Ruby developer instead of a Java developer."

It's all straightforward but it's also akin to having a drawer full of adapter cables because every device needs a slightly different charging cable. Like, yeah, I'll deal with it but I'd be a much happier consumer if I could just use the same boring USB for everything, you know?

Vincent Pretre
2020-06-02 02:38:01

*Thread Reply:* it’s indeed true that we did not think that much of direct consumers from Gherkin. We did our best to integrate lots of new stuff into Gherkin / cucumber and also discovering stuff with Protobuf (for example the name ghange from capital to camel casse, iirc the gem we ussed did not properly implement the protobuf good practices)

Vincent Pretre
2020-06-02 02:38:18

*Thread Reply:* that said we’ve arrived at a stable level now hopefully 🙂

Vincent Pretre
2020-06-02 02:34:58

cucumber-ruby 4.0 is out: https://rubygems.org/gems/cucumber/versions/4.0.0 🙂

🎉 Dana Scheider (they/he), MarkSweetlove, karamosky, olleolleolle
enkessler
2020-06-03 05:18:16

Question: Is the JRuby 9.1.17 part of Cucumber's CI?

I see 9.2 in the CI results but not any earlier versions. I ask because Ruby 2.3 (which is what JRuby 9.1.17 maps to) is the minumum supported version for Cucumber but my own CI jobs are failing for JRuby 9.1.17 but only when using the current release of Cucumber.

Vincent Pretre
2020-06-03 09:32:45

Indeed we don't test all JRuby, only 9.2. Could be interresting to try with earlier one but not much time for that on my side.

enkessler
2020-06-13 08:44:13

Idle commentary: While I understand the reasoning behind changing the name of the gem from gherkin to cucumber-gherkin (to make the name consistent across various language libraries) and the decision to not change the namespace internally (i.e. still using require 'gherkin' instead of require 'cucumber-gherkin'), those decisions have resulted in the loss of simple dependency resolution. According to all conventions and tools, they are separate gems and so will not conflict with each other but, because they effectively are the same gem from a code standpoint, they cannot co-exist in the same runtime without stepping on each other's toes. This is causing some Dependency Hell for projects that end up transitively needing both gems because Bundler (or anything else) doesn't know that they are the same library.

enkessler
2020-06-13 08:54:36

The net result is that I am now limited to using cucumber 2.2.0 in several of my projects. Even 3.x Cucumber has been 'broken' because of the namespace issue. Cucumber 3.x doesn't use cucumber-gherkin according to its gem specification but Ruby will still end up in that code at runtime.

enkessler
2020-06-13 08:55:14

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-06-22 08:52:44

Hi @Vincent Pretre - any idea about how this bug could have made it to a release? https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/issues/1074

BillyRuffian (https://github.com/BillyRuffian)
#1074 cucumber/gherkin/ruby 13.0.0 Gherkin::Parser instantiates Gherkin::AstBuilder with wrong arguments
<p><strong>Summary</strong></p> <p><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/ruby/lib/gherkin/parser.rb#L59">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/ruby/lib/gherkin/parser.rb#L59</a> Parser's initialize with no arguments passed creates a new AST Buider with no args.</p> <p><a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/ruby/lib/gherkin/ast_builder.rb#L6">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/gherkin/ruby/lib/gherkin/ast_builder.rb#L6</a> AST Builder takes a mandatory argument.</p> <p><strong>Expected Behavior</strong></p> <p>Expected an initialized Parser object.</p> <p><strong>Current Behavior</strong></p> <pre><code>ArgumentError: wrong number of arguments (given 0, expected 1) ruby/2.6.0/gems/cucumber-gherkin-13.0.0/lib/gherkin/ast_builder.rb:6:in `initialize' ruby/2.6.0/gems/cucumber-gherkin-13.0.0/lib/gherkin/parser.rb:59:in `new' ruby/2.6.0/gems/cucumber-gherkin-13.0.0/lib/gherkin/parser.rb:59:in `initialize' </code></pre> <p><strong>Possible Solution</strong></p> <p>AST Builder's initializer should take an option argument with a default id generator.</p> <p><strong>Steps to Reproduce (for bugs)</strong></p> <ol><li>Gherkin::Parser.new</li> </ol> <p><strong>Context &amp; Motivation</strong></p> <p>Using the parser to scan feature files for compliance. We've down-graded to Cucumber 3.2.</p>

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>

luke
2020-07-28 04:35:42

@Vincent Pretre any thoughts on this: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1432

orien (https://github.com/orien)
#1432 Obtain feature name in before hook
<p><strong>Describe the bug</strong></p> <p>In version 3 it is possible to obtain the name of the current feature from <code>Before</code> and <code>After</code> hooks.</p> <pre><code>Before do |scenario| feature_name = scenario.feature.name #… end </code></pre> <p>In version 4 this seems impossible as the <code>feature</code> method has been removed and I can see no replacement.</p> <pre><code>Before do |scenario| feature_name = scenario.feature.name # -&amp;gt; undefined method `feature' for #&amp;lt;Cucumber::RunningTestCase::TestCase:0x00007f9b307ae180&amp;gt; (NoMethodError) end </code></pre> <p><strong>To Reproduce</strong><br /> Steps to reproduce the behavior:</p> <ol><li>Install version 4</li><li>Add <code>Before</code> hook obtaining feature name</li><li>Run cucumber</li><li>See error</li> </ol> <p><strong>Expected behavior</strong></p> <p>Be able to obtain the running feature name from <code>Before</code> and <code>After</code> hooks.</p> <p><strong>Context &amp; Motivation</strong></p> <p>Providing a replacement for this would ease the migration path to version 4.0.0 as integrations rely on this data.</p> <p>For example, the VCR gem uses <a href="https://github.com/vcr/vcr/blob/v6.0.0/lib/vcr/test_frameworks/cucumber.rb#L51-L52">the scenario and feature names</a> to determine which cassette to load.</p>
Comments
4
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
luke
2020-07-28 04:36:10

essentially methods removed from scenario block in hooks. ideally some form of backwards compatibility fix or more documentation

Vincent Pretre
2020-07-28 06:38:37

@luke I’ve seen it (and I thought I had answered it ...) - seems like something we should tackle, although the current representation of the AST will not help us a lot here. We’d have to set some walker that maps the features to which each scenario belongs and make it available when running the hooks (or in the RunningScenario object if I correctly recall the name). So not really a simple thing but it should indeed be done I think.

luke
2020-07-28 06:50:13

oki, so the massive change from what methods were available in 3->4 isn't an easy one to revert?

Vincent Pretre
2020-07-28 07:44:33

to be honest, this change was done before I joined the team, I don’t really know how and when that happened

Vincent Pretre
2020-07-28 07:44:58

I guess it was changed when the messages have been introduced and that the AST comes as messages

Vincent Pretre
2020-07-28 07:45:14

I tried to find where this came from, but wasn’t successful 😕

luke
2020-07-28 07:54:10

no probs, just I would say it's one of the more common queries.

brasmusson
2020-07-28 10:53:34

*Thread Reply:* Because the most common misuse of hooks is to use them for logging/reporting?

brasmusson
2020-07-28 08:54:52

@Vincent Pretre @luke The long story. Cucumber-Ruby was the first cucumber implementations. Originally the execution of feature file was done by iterating the AST. This made the cucumber implementation fragile and error prone. But the whole AST was available when executing, which means that the hooks could access the AST. In Cucumber-Ruby 2.0 the concept of compiling feature files was introduced. However the compiled test cases includes links back to the AST, so the whole AST was still available when executing, that is was still accessible from hooks. Then the concept of Pickles was created and the responsibility of compiling feature files became part of the responsibilities of the gherkin library (https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/gherkin#pickles).

The introduction of Pickles means IMHO that the central part of any cucumber implementation is a loop execute(Pickle), and it also specifies that the data available when executing is only the Pickle. Since only the Pickle is available when executing the hooks consequently can access only data of the Pickle - not the data of the AST from which the Pickle was compiled.

The gherkin compiler and Pickle was introduced into Cucumber-Ruby i v4, and consequently hooks can no longer access the AST. Since Cucumber-Ruby users have been used to be able to access the AST from hooks, many of them now miss being able to do that.

To me this issue boils down to this. a) Should Pickles be re-thought or not? Is executing feature files in cucumber implementations essentially executing Pickles compiled by the gherkin library? b) What is really the purpose of hooks? Is it to enable the execution, or is it to do all sort of stuff like reporting, logging etc. etc?

My best interpretation of the architecuture of Cucumber (TBH I have not that involved the last couple of years) is that a) executing Pickles is essentially what cucumber implementations do, and b) the purpose of hooks is to enable the execution (not reporting, logging etc - even though that is a very common misuse or hooks). Therefore my conclusion is the it should not be possible access the feature name in hooks. Which is not the popular conclusion I'm sure.

Vincent Pretre
2020-07-28 09:06:05

*Thread Reply:* thanks for the explanations @brasmusson 🙂

brasmusson
2020-07-28 09:11:39

*Thread Reply:* See the edited post

enkessler
2020-07-28 10:51:27

*Thread Reply:* 1. Pickles keeping all of the syntactic noise of the AST away from Cucumber is good, yes, but they do need to contain any needed semantic information about the test. Things like "what's the name of this test", "which feature did it come from", and "what tags are in scope for it" are all pieces of useful information to include in the pickled package that is The Test.

  1. If doing logging/reporting/etc. via hooks is a misuse, then the natural question that users will have is "then where am I supposed to do it?".
brasmusson
2020-07-28 11:09:27

*Thread Reply:* > "what's the name of this test" -> The name attribute of the pickle

> "which feature did it come from" -> The uri attribute of the pickle

> "what tags are in scope for it" -> The tags attribute of the pickle

> [logging/reporting] "then where am I supposed to do it?" Initially there was the formatter interface. Now through listening on the message/event stream.

Yes, documentation/examples on how to do both custom reporting and logging etc using the message/event stream are far from sufficient if considering logging/reporting/etc via hooks a misuse.

enkessler
2020-07-28 11:11:21

*Thread Reply:* Then we are agreed that pickles are a good thing. :)

luke
2020-07-29 00:24:41

*Thread Reply:* I think also people think of cucumber at the front-end. And front-end the block variable on a hook is called scenario so I'd expect most info on the scenario.

brasmusson
2020-07-29 07:36:50

*Thread Reply:* That the block variable on a hook is called scenario should most likely be seen as technical debt from the Cucumber-Ruby v2 release. From that release was is executed is always a TestCase and never a scenario. What changed in Cucumber-Ruby v4 was that the TestCase is created from from a Pickle so the TestCase cannot provide access to AST data. In Cucucmber-Ruby v2-3 when the TestCase was created from the AST and had ruby object links into the AST, AST data could be accessed through the TestCase. If the name of the block variable of hooks had been changed in Cucumber-Ruby v2 (to test_case) to reflect the Cucumber-Ruby v2 architecture we would hopefully have less confusion now. I believe that the choice of not changing the name in Cucumber-Ruby v2 was made to make it look a bit more backward compatible than it in reality was.

luke
2020-07-29 07:40:05

*Thread Reply:* Fair point. That's something I think we should fix up.

Also you mentioned earlier about hooks being used incorrectly. I don't think asking for information on a running scenario would necessarily qualifying as being used incorrectly. Whether they should be used in the hooks is a fair comment, but the info I would argue "should" be readily available.

In RSpec for example it is, and in minitest. And I imagine in other languages accessing the name of the test being ran is a feasible use case.

brasmusson
2020-07-29 09:05:55

*Thread Reply:* My understanding of the cucumber architecture is that it has two important extension points: a) the hooks extension point. This extension point has the purpose of performing additional interactions with the SUT to enable the successful execution of the test case (for a scenario in a feature file). b) the formatter (previously) of event/message stream (now) extension point. This extension point has the purpose of enabling collection/publishing information of what happens during the execution in cucumber.

From this understanding using hooks for logging and reporting is misuse, because the architecture provides another extension point for exactly that purpose.

> accessing the name of the test being ran is a feasible use case. Again the name of the test being ran is the name of the TestCase and it is available to hooks. The name of the TestCase is the name of the Pickle which is base on the name of the Scenario in the feature file.

When the Pickle was introduced in the gherkin architecture, it was also the statement of "this is the information needed for the successful execution of a test case from scenario in a feature file", and also the statement of "this is the information needed for the hooks extension point".

If we think that the hooks extension point should have access to more information, then we should change the Pickle to contain that information.

👍 luke
tooky
2020-07-29 12:20:12

*Thread Reply:* > I believe that the choice of not changing the name in Cucumber-Ruby v2 was made to make it look a bit more backward compatible than it in reality was For completeness, our goal with v2 was to be entirely backwards compatible with v1 despite the fact we had completely rewritten the execution model. In fact, we only went for a major release because we weren’t confident we had enough coverage to be sure we hadn’t broken some public API 🙂

tooky
2020-07-29 12:25:49

*Thread Reply:* …aaaand, when we say > the block variable is called scenario do we mean:

After do |scenario| end Because… that’s really a docs error. Perhaps it should be:

After do |pickle| end

tooky
2020-07-29 12:26:25

*Thread Reply:* or test_case!

brasmusson
2020-07-30 00:16:40

*Thread Reply:* > block variable on a hook is called scenario Yes, I think it is because of: After do |scenario| end

Marcos Bellucci
2020-07-31 15:26:27

@Marcos Bellucci has joined the channel

enkessler
2020-08-17 11:55:52

So I've decided to take another crack at working on the Cucumber gems and I've got the monorepo cloned and Docker is set up. However, the gherkin sub-project does not appear to build cleanly. Further, how much of it fails seems to depend on at what level of the monorepo I am running make . That is, running LANGUAGES=ruby make from the root of the monorepo does not have the same failures for the Ruby version of Gherkin as running make from within gherkin/ruby.

Is anyone here familiar with working with the monorepo?

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-08-17 13:41:04

Hi @enkessler we recommend running the build in a docker terminal because running a build requires various tools to be installed. After installing docker, try this from the root dir:

make docker-run
cd gherkin
make

Hope this helps!

2020-08-17 13:46:46

```winpty make docker-run

now inside of the docker container

make clean NOCROSSCOMPILE=1 make`` Thewinptyis becausemakedoesn't like not having a TTY shell or some such thing. The output is not particularly useful because it doesn't say thing about the individual projects, so running the top levelmake` during development isn't a good route.

now inside of the docker container

now inside of the docker container

cd gherkin LANGUAGES=ruby make`` It's at least useful output now, but it still doesn't work due to trying to load files that don't exist. Maybe themake` task was supposed to generate the file or something but it's not.

CONTRIBUTING_NEW.md
<pre><code># Contributing to Cucumber First off - thank you for contributing to Cucumber! ## Overview This [monorepo](&lt;https://gomonorepo.org/&gt;) contains various components (libraries) used by Cucumber, such as: ** The Gherkin parser ** The Cucumber Expressions engine ** The Tag Expressions parser ** The Cucumber Protocol messages ** ...and a few more bits and bobs. The Cucumber implementations themselves live in separate Git repositories: ** [cucumber-jvm](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm&gt;) ** [cucumber-ruby](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby&gt;) ** [cucumber-js](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js&gt;) ** [SpecFlow](&lt;https://github.com/techtalk/SpecFlow&gt;) ** And various [other](&lt;https://cucumber.io/docs/installation/&gt;) implementations The libraries in this monorepo are implemented in many different languages (Java, TypeScript, Ruby, C# and a few more). ## Building You have a few options for building this repo as outlined below. ### Building on Docker You need a lot of various tools to build this repo, and to make this easy we have created a [docker](&lt;https://www.docker.com/&gt;) image with all the required build tools installed. To use this you need Docker installed, and a bash shell on your host OS: </code></pre> <p>make docker-run make clean NO<em>CROSS</em>COMPILE=1 make</p> <pre><code> You can leave out `NO_CROSS_COMPILE=1` to cross-compile go executables, but this will slow down your build. The build will take a while the first time you run it, but subsequent calls to `make` should be a lot faster because downloaded files will be cached, and `make` will only rebuild packages that you have changed. The git repo is mounted as a volume in the running Docker container, so you can edit files with your favourite IDE/editor on the host OS. If you are only making changes to a particular package, you can build just that package by changing into the relevant directory and running `make`. The benefit of building in Docker is that you don't need to install anything (except for Docker). The downside is that the build is slower than running on your host OS. ### Building on MacOS/Linux If you contribute regularly to Cucumber we recommend installing all the required tools on your host OS. You can find a list of those tools by looking at `Dockerfile`. The build process is the same as within Docker, except that you run your commands on the host OS. </code></pre> <p>make clean make</p> <pre><code> ### Building on CircleCI Whenever you push code to this repo, or create a [pull request](&lt;https://help.github.com/en/articles/about-pull-requests&gt;), CircleCI will build your code. CircleCI will build the packages in parallel, so a full build will complete a lot faster than a local build. ### Building a subset Define `PACKAGES` and/or `LANGUAGES` to only build a subset of packages / languages. Examples: </code></pre> <p>LANGUAGES=javascript make LANGUAGES="javascript ruby" make PACKAGES="messages gherkin" make</p> <pre><code> ### Using yarn instead of npm If you prefer to use yarn instead of npm: </code></pre> <p>NPM=yarn LANGUAGES=javascript make</p> <pre><code> ## Troubleshooting ### Errors during Node builds You may encounter timeouts or errors when building some npm modules. If this happens, try building the module with yarn (`NPM=yarn` - see above). If you're still experiencing errors or timeouts, try replacing `file:../..` dependencies in `package.json` with the latest release of the package. If you do, please do not commit that change. ## Encrypted secrets Some files in the repo are encrypted [git-crypt](&lt;https://www.agwa.name/projects/git-crypt/&gt;). Look inside `/.gitattributes` to find out which ones. Releases can only be made when these files are decrypted. See [RELEASE_PROCESS.md](./RELEASE_PROCESS.md) for details. </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>

luke
2020-10-27 07:27:04

Minor thing I've noticed.

When being asked to provide a step for a literal / the suggestion in ruby is for \/ which isn't valid. It needs to be \\/

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-10-28 04:54:46

*Thread Reply:* Are you talking about printed step definition snippets @luke? In what way is \/ not valid? Is the Cucumber Expressions parser choking on it?

Aslak Hellesøy
2020-10-28 04:58:36

*Thread Reply:* AFICT \/ is valid Ruby when used in both single-quoted and double-quoted strings, but they yield different results:

• p '\/' => "\\/" • p '\\/' => "\\/" • p "\/" => "/" • p "\\/" => "\\/"

luke
2020-10-28 04:58:38

*Thread Reply:* If I type a step that includes \/ it's not valid.

Can someone here please sniff that issue and perhaps write a few words to explain how an implementer might solve that, using the newer replacement methods? I can get a link real quick.

👍 luke
olleolleolle
2021-01-07 12:35:04

https://github.com/vcr/vcr/issues/843

dannyvanhoof (https://github.com/dannyvanhoof)
#843 Cucumber 5.2.0 no longer supports the .feature method to get the name of a test case, used in "use_scenario_name"
<p>The VCR method <a href="https://github.com/vcr/vcr/blob/v6.0.0/lib/vcr/test_frameworks/cucumber.rb#L51-L52">https://github.com/vcr/vcr/blob/v6.0.0/lib/vcr/test_frameworks/cucumber.rb#L51-L52</a> still uses the "feature" method, which is no longer supported by cucumber 5.2.0.<br /> Are there any plans to fix this issue?</p>

2021-02-12 06:34:16

Hi, Who's responsible for making a release? If I upgrade some dependencies in a PR for cucumber-ruby and cucumber-ruby-core, should I include the bump of the version?

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-02-12 09:38:38

Anyone in the Cucumber Open core team can make a release. This is a group of about a dozen people who have access to release secrets.

Leave version numbers unchanged - this will be done when a release is made.

luke
2021-02-16 01:39:24

This might help us not need the cucumber protobuf ruby fork https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/pull/7923

rdubya (https://github.com/rdubya)
#7923 Fill out JRuby support
<p>This gets the Ruby gem to be able to be used on JRuby. Almost all Ruby tests are passing with a couple minor changes. There are a significant number of compatibility tests that are failing, but I figured this would at least get something in place that could be expanded upon by others in the community.</p> <p>This is related to the following issues:</p> <p>• <a href="https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/issues/1594">#1594</a> • <a href="https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/issues/1820">#1820</a> • <a href="https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/issues/3090">#3090</a> • <a href="https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/issues/3650">#3650</a> • <a href="https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/issues/7831">#7831</a></p>

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-02-26 08:20:32

*Thread Reply:* None of the 3 modules can have conflicting dependencies. Changing one of them to use messages v14 while the others are on v13 will break the build.

@matt-SmartBear can explain more - IIRC it was he and @tooky who broke it up in 3 modules a few years back.

  3. Trigger a full build of cucumber-ruby when cucumber-ruby-wire or cucumber-ruby-core are modified (not sure how best to do that)

Aslak Hellesøy

*Thread Reply:* This needs updating too: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/d962d8945a8249ef369238e5bc4ed20960e3c955/cucumber.gemspec#L24-L29

cucumber.gemspec:24-29
<pre><code> s.add_dependency 'cucumber-create-meta', '~&amp;gt; 2.0', '&amp;gt;= 2.0.2' s.add_dependency 'cucumber-cucumber-expressions', '~&amp;gt; 10.3', '&amp;gt;= 10.3.0' s.add_dependency 'cucumber-gherkin', '~&amp;gt; 15.0', '&amp;gt;= 15.0.2' s.add_dependency 'cucumber-html-formatter', '~&amp;gt; 9.0', '&amp;gt;= 9.0.0' s.add_dependency 'cucumber-messages', '~&amp;gt; 13.1', '&amp;gt;= 13.1.0' s.add_dependency 'cucumber-wire', '~&amp;gt; 4.0', '&amp;gt;= 4.0.1' </code></pre>

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-04-06 07:05:53

Hi all - I've started to upgrade cucumber-ruby to use the latest gems. To simplify this, I have created a new gherkin8x branch:

• https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-meta/pull/5 There is currently one failure: https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/1062/workflows/087d67f7-b035-405f-b75e-4de99d79c89c/jobs/10143

aslakhellesoy (https://github.com/aslakhellesoy)
#5 Support branches. Upgrade cucumber-* dependencies
<p>This simplifies the workflow by automatically using local code if it exists. No more need to set a lot of environment variables.</p>

👍 Aurélien Reeves
matt-SmartBear
2021-04-06 12:14:04

*Thread Reply:* So am I right in thinking is this a problem with how the HTML formatter is being packaged, rather than a problem with how cucumber-ruby is being tested?

Aurélien Reeves
2021-04-07 00:33:12

*Thread Reply:* I think the opposite.

cucumber-ruby should be tested with production-like dependencies.

What would be the point into testing cucumber-ruby with a dependency which is not yet ready for production - ie not packaged?

On a dev environment, I think it is up to the developer to make sure the dependencies are properly packaged when trying to integrate it with cucumber-ruby

Aurélien Reeves
2021-04-07 00:37:12

*Thread Reply:* cf. https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1519#issuecomment-814663445

aurelien-reeves (https://github.com/aurelien-reeves)
Comment on #1519 Gherkin 18x
<p>For developers, and on the CI, we never use the real depencencies, but local code, or the one in github - the one from the master branches I presume</p> <p>That mean we never really test the gem with its actual dependencies?</p> <p>I would suggest to move the development dependencies in a <code>Gemfile.local</code>, as documented here: <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#installing-your-own-gems">https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#installing-your-own-gems</a>.</p> <p>That way the developer can have full control on its own environment, but the CI remains more close to the production gem.</p> <p>We could complete the contributing doc and provide a <code>Gemfile.local.monorepo.sample</code> with the changes you have done in that PR to make the tests with local code easier</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
Aslak Hellesøy
2021-04-07 02:02:11

*Thread Reply:* > What would be the point into testing cucumber-ruby with a dependency which is not yet ready for production - ie not packaged? When we make changes to low level libraries in the monorepo, we'll know almost immediately if we've broken something downstream (i.e. cucumber-ruby).

More details here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1519#issuecomment-814737819

aslakhellesoy (https://github.com/aslakhellesoy)
Comment on #1519 Gherkin 18x
<p>&gt; That mean we never really test the gem with its actual dependencies?</p> <p>I've just pushed some changes to make sure we also have jobs that run against released dependencies (currently only with ruby 2.5 - when this works we can do the same for all ruby version).</p> <p>I think it's important to have CI jobs that do both:</p> <p>• Unreleased dependencies will highlight problems early • Released dependencies give us the confidence that we can release</p> <p>WDYT?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
Aslak Hellesøy

Aurélien Reeves
2021-04-13 06:20:56

cucumber-ruby is ready to be released!

cucumber-ruby-wire had to be fixed after upgrading cucumber-expressions. It was still using version 10, so the version 11 seemed to impact cucumber-wire a little bit. Cf. https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby-wire/commit/6564cf5c85dc1ea6e67de03e9c8f13fe12376e9c

Also, some deprecation in cucumber-ruby are due to be removed. Here's the PR: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1523 Any objection into merging it?

#1523 Remove deprecated `embed` and `puts`
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>

Aslak Hellesøy

✅ Aurélien Reeves
luke
2021-06-18 04:14:05

Minor thought.

cucumber-ruby depends on gherkin and messages

However gherkin ALSO depends on messages.

luke
2021-06-18 04:14:19

should we therefore remove cucumber-ruby depending on messages? to avoid having to manage the dep twice?

👍 Dana Scheider (they/he)
Aslak Hellesøy
2021-06-18 04:21:19

Sounds like a good idea to me - that way we avoid accidentally ending up with different versions.

enkessler
2021-06-21 18:43:04

Does cucumber-ruby use cucumber-messages directly? If so, then it ought to be a declared dependency. That other dependencies (i.e. cucumber-gherkin ) might also depend on the same gem is incidental. It's not really "managing the dependency twice" because cucumber-ruby and cucumber-gherkin are two separate gems. That it might be the same person that is doing the maintenance is also incidental.

Regarding ending up with different versions, that's Bundler's problem to resolve. Unless the problem that is being suggested is that we might end up with different incompatible versions of things. If that's the case, then I believe that we've already had that conversation recently.

brasmusson
2021-06-22 04:01:20

Yes, cucumber-ruby does use cucumber-messages directly. It both produce messages of cucumber-messages itself and consumes messages of cucumber-messages that gherkin has produced.

Rachel G
2021-06-22 06:16:06

@Rachel G has joined the channel

Oscar Barrios
2021-07-07 03:31:16

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1561|#1561 Suppress unnecessary warnings about ANSICON in integrated terminal of vscode>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>On the integrated terminal of vscode, Cucumber always warns about ANSICON as below.</p> <pre><code>****** WARNING: You must use ANSICON 1.31 or higher (&lt;https://github.com/adoxa/ansicon/&gt;) to get coloured output on Windows </code></pre> <p>This behavior was discussed in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1163">#1163</a> or <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1119">#1119</a>, but unfortunately has not resolved yet.</p> <p>Because the environment variable <code>VSCODE_PID</code> mentioned in <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/issues/1163">#1163</a> is already obsolete, it seems to be good to check the value of <code>TERM_PROGRAM</code> instead of it.</p> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>• Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)</p> <p><strong>Note to other contributors</strong> <strong>Update required of <a href="http://cucumber.io/docs**|cucumber.io/docs**">http://cucumber.io/docs</strong>|cucumber.io/docs<strong></a> **Checklist:</strong></p> <p>Your PR is ready for review once the following checklist is<br /> complete. You can also add some checks if you want to.</p> <p>☑︎ Tests have been added for any changes to behaviour of the code • I have tested the above change with my local copy of the gem, and I am able to see the correct color output from cucumber in the vscode integrated terminal. ☑︎ New and existing tests are passing locally and on CI ☑︎ <code>bundle exec rubocop</code> reports no offenses ☑︎ (N/A) RDoc comments have been updated ☑︎ (N/A) CHANGELOG.md has been updated</p>

<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
Aurélien Reeves
2021-07-13 07:03:38

Could be nice to release the following patch before releasing cucumber-ruby: https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1655

<https://github.com/cucumber/common/pull/1655|#1655 Convert ruby messages duration.nanos to integer>
<p><code>duration.nanos</code> is described in the schema as being an integer. It was already the case with protobuf.</p> <p>With the new DTOs, <code>duration.nanos</code> became a float. When using the json-formatter to convert ndjson to "legacy" json, an error is raised:</p> <pre><code>ERROR: json: cannot unmarshal number 127100.0 into Go struct field Duration.testStepFinished.testStepResult.duration.nanos of type int64 </code></pre> <p>Converting nanos to integer should fix this.</p> <p><strong>How Has This Been Tested?</strong></p> <p>As durations are removed when validating messages as part of the neutralize-json scripts, this is not properly tested yet in the mono-repo.<br /> I encounter this issue while trying to reactivate the CCK tests with cucumber-ruby. So there will be at least that way to test it.</p> <p><strong>Types of changes</strong></p> <p>☑︎ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue).</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>☑︎ I've added tests for my code. ☑︎ I have updated the CHANGELOG accordingly.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common">cucumber/common</a>

🎉 matt-SmartBear
luke
2021-07-26 08:27:22

Question. Do we think the duration of a scenario is something that should be hook accessible>?

Aurélien Reeves
2021-07-26 08:43:29

*Thread Reply:* IMO: why not? 🤔

brasmusson
2021-07-26 23:09:26

*Thread Reply:* The duration of the scenario is not known until all the test steps (for both hooks and feature file step) so what would duration of the scenario represent when made available to a hook or test step. Normally the duration of a scenario is the difference between the timestamp of the test case started and test case finished events.

luke
2021-07-28 03:30:01

*Thread Reply:* Sorry I should just clarify, this is current not available, because of the object being pushed back not exposing it. I had to proper hack away to get it.

I'll create a PR to expose this in the Ruby object model.

👍 Aurélien Reeves
Aurélien Reeves
2021-07-28 05:40:39

*Thread Reply:* What was your need at first?

luke
2021-07-28 05:58:24

*Thread Reply:* generate runtimes for each scenario for some logging / improvement. Without using the Around hooks (As they're super bad).

Aurélien Reeves
2021-07-28 06:51:57

*Thread Reply:* """ Without using the Around hooks (As they're super bad). """

I've already read that, but why? Why are "around" hooks discouraged?

luke
2021-07-28 07:50:32

*Thread Reply:* because there's a bunch of bugs with them and we were meant to be removing them for ages.

luke
2021-07-28 07:51:02

*Thread Reply:* They're not consistent with the other implementations, and you can achieve most of what you want by using aftersteps / before/after and other combinations which are just better.

brasmusson
2021-07-28 08:52:45

*Thread Reply:* As the runtime of the hooks (which are test steps just as much as the steps from the feature files), no hook can get the runtime of the scenario. The duration of the scenario is the time difference between the timestamp of the test case finished and the test case started events, and the test case finished event is generated after all hooks had executed. To get the current runtime of a scenario, an event listener plugin is needed (the duration is part of the result data of the test case finished event.

luke
2021-07-26 08:27:33

It is accessible for a test step, but not a bunch of steps (scenario).

yosukei3108
2021-07-27 04:31:32

Aurélien Reeves
2021-07-29 03:14:49

Some settings for cucumber-ruby-wire have been tweaked in the repo on github: • Required signed commits on the main branch: we discuss that, this is a security measure that can be worked-around with unsigned commits in a PR • Required linear history for the main branch: see below • Disallow merge commits: this is to allow unsigned commits on a PR to be squashed back into main as part of a signed squashed commit Also, following the work that is done on cucumber/build to make life easier when releasing things, I suggest to start applying those on cucumber-ruby-wire. It feels like a good candidate to me. That's why the "required linear history" settings.

If any objection, we can easily revert those changes.

What do you think?

👍:skin_tone_2: matt-SmartBear
luke
2021-07-30 02:25:44

so I'm currently re-working our jenkins pipeline to now chunk our builds up, so each executor runs only a portion of the tests, But we've also updated our cucumber version a bit. So now feels like a good time to explore cucumber reports.

Quick question though. Using these reports it uses the message stream right? Would that be affected if multiple nodes all push to the same stream?

matt-SmartBear
2021-08-03 11:27:57

*Thread Reply:* I don't know. @Vincent Pretre or @Aslak Hellesøy would know but I think they're on their hols.

matt-SmartBear
2021-08-03 11:28:07

*Thread Reply:* Try it!

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-03 14:22:55

*Thread Reply:* You can push as many streams as you want using the same token. Each stream you push becomes a distinct report under the same report collection.

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-03 14:24:29

*Thread Reply:* You don’t push to a stream. You push a stream to a collection identified by tour token.

matt-SmartBear
2021-08-03 14:25:45

*Thread Reply:* So Luke is running one suite of tests distributed across multiple nodes, each node will have a separate report?

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-03 14:27:37

*Thread Reply:* Correct. There is no support for merging reports yet. But they will show up under the same report collection.

We want to add support for merging of course.

luke
2021-08-05 01:22:54

*Thread Reply:* cool, that's fine 🙂 I think it'll be interesting to look into this down the line.

Also with JSON in my eyes it should be easier to merge than with protobufs (But maybe I'm only saying that because I understand json!)

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-08-06 08:01:27

*Thread Reply:* We don’t use protobuf anymore, and when we did it wasn’t exposed in reports. We use ndjson, which you’ll understand if you understand json.

luke
2021-08-03 03:05:17

I remember seeing someone recently find some error with cucumber where it was using like a monkeypatched activesupport method which we couldn't explain. I'm seeing a similar thing with using parallel_tests, can anyone remember what the issue was / if we fixed it.

Aurélien Reeves
2021-08-03 04:41:15

*Thread Reply:* That was related to the way we pad strings

We had monkey patched ruby strings. We replaced it with a proper helper

If I were to go and add a monkeypatch into VCR, along the lines of the last submitted comment - would that be.. bad?

<https://github.com/vcr/vcr/issues/825|#825 Cucumber v4 incompatibility>
<p>There seems to be an incompatibility with the <code>VCR.cucumber_tags</code> functionality and the newly released Cucumber version 4.</p> <p>See the following backtrace detailing the error I am experiencing.</p> <pre><code>6: from /usr/local/bundle/ruby/gems/2.6.0/gems/cucumber-core-7.0.0/lib/cucumber/core/test/step.rb:35:in `execute' 5: from /usr/local/bundle/ruby/gems/2.6.0/gems/cucumber-core-7.0.0/lib/cucumber/core/test/action.rb:24:in `execute' 4: from /usr/local/bundle/ruby/gems/2.6.0/gems/cucumber-4.0.1/lib/cucumber/runtime/before_hooks.rb:25:in `block (2 levels) in before_hooks' 3: from /usr/local/bundle/ruby/gems/2.6.0/gems/cucumber-4.0.1/lib/cucumber/glue/hook.rb:22:in `invoke' 2: from /usr/local/bundle/ruby/gems/2.6.0/gems/cucumber-4.0.1/lib/cucumber/glue/invoke_in_world.rb:26:in `cucumber_instance_exec_in' 1: from /usr/local/bundle/ruby/gems/2.6.0/gems/vcr-6.0.0/lib/vcr/test_frameworks/cucumber.rb:51:in `Before' /usr/local/bundle/ruby/2.6.0/delegate.rb:87:in `method_missing': undefined method `feature' for #&amp;lt;Cucumber::RunningTestCase::TestCase:0x00007ff5877dee78&amp;gt; (NoMethodError) </code></pre> <p><a href="https://github.com/vcr/vcr/blob/v6.0.0/lib/vcr/test_frameworks/cucumber.rb#L51">https://github.com/vcr/vcr/blob/v6.0.0/lib/vcr/test_frameworks/cucumber.rb#L51</a></p> <p>VCR 6.0.0<br /> Ruby 2.6.6<br /> Gem 3.1.4<br /> Rails 5.2.4.3<br /> Cucumber 4.0.1</p>

olleolleolle
2021-08-10 07:34:28

*Thread Reply:* I think it’s for managing a few different cassette files for each configured Cucumber “tag” (or “tags”).

matt-SmartBear
2021-08-13 13:29:38

I've made a PR to cucumber-ruby to add release automation. It would be great to have as many of you as possible give it a review so you have your heads around how the release process will work.

olleolleolle
2021-08-14 01:35:03

*Thread Reply:* Thanks for a thorough PR! Or, set of PRs, I learned a lot

matt-SmartBear
2021-08-13 13:30:39

The idea is that anyone with the commit bit can trigger the "pre-release" workflow which creates a PR to a release branch, but only members of the @cucumber/cucumber-ruby github team can merge those PRs and trigger the actual release script (which has access to a RUBYGEMS_API_KEY secret)

mvz
2021-08-16 23:44:57

*Thread Reply:* I have a couple of questions: • Do these release branches have to stick around? • Which commit gets tagged? • Will the current key I have to release Aruba become invalid?

matt-SmartBear
2021-08-17 09:14:27

*Thread Reply:* Hey @mvz, thanks for taking an interest!

> Do these release branches have to stick around? I don't think they do, but at the moment I don't quite have the confidence to delete the branch at the end of the release script. We could do that though, to reduce branch clutter. I did initially try using a single release branch but I found it was getting too complicated moving the base/head of that branch around. We could revisit that idea too.

> Which commits get tagged? Good question! The tagging happens when you create the GitHub Release, and I realised yesterday that, unless you specify which commit to tag, it automatically tags the HEAD of the main branch. This is not quite what we want, because it's possible that other commits have been pushed to that branch while the release was happening. In fact, we want to tag the commit where the pre-release branch was made, but that's unreliable as you might have deleted that branch when merging the release PR.

The strategy I have in mind right now to solve this is to look up the final commit in the release PR, and tag that. If you have other suggestions, I'd love to hear them.

> Will the current key I have to release Aruba become invalid? At the moment I don't have any plans to retire our existing secrets, though I think that long-term once we have an automated release pipeline that we trust, we should consider doing that. My goal here is to make it easier for all of us to do releases, easier for regular committers to prepare releases, and to remove the need for people to have the secrets repo cloned to their machines.

Do you release Aruba via the cukebot account, or from your own RubyGems account?

<https://github.com/cucumber/common/issues/1688#issuecomment-899864133|Comment on #1688 Automate releases>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common">cucumber/common</a>
<https://github.com/cucumber/common/issues/1688#issuecomment-899869198|Comment on #1688 Automate releases>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common">cucumber/common</a>
mvz
2021-08-18 00:10:21

*Thread Reply:* Thanks @matt-SmartBear for the detailed explanation. Regarding tagging the correct commit, isn't the tip of the release the commit to tag, since it's the commit the gem is built from? If I understand things correctly, that branch should definitely exist when the release workflow is triggered. I suppose to avoid having dangling commits with tags that are not on any branch, merging of the pre-release PR should not result in a merge commit? I'm using the cukebot account to release Aruba, but I'd be happy to switch to using my own account which has 2-factor authentication.

matt-SmartBear
2021-08-18 09:27:14

*Thread Reply:* > Thanks @matt-SmartBear for the detailed explanation. Regarding tagging the correct commit, isn't the tip of the release the commit to tag, since it's the commit the gem is built from? If I understand things correctly, that branch should definitely exist when the release workflow is triggered. > I suppose to avoid having dangling commits with tags that are not on any branch, merging of the pre-release PR should not result in a merge commit? So yeah, I've wrestled with this a bit.

If we could enforce merge commits (and not squashes) into the release branch we could tag that commit and merge it back into main but squash commits seem to mess things up and not merge back properly. As far as I can tell we have no way to allow (or even enforce) squash merges into main but merge commits into release - the setting is repo-wide.

My thinking is that the released commit (which may be a squash of all the commits in the release) is really just a temporary artefact of the build process, and the commit we want to tag is the one on the main branch, where it came from.

mvz
2021-08-21 00:37:41

*Thread Reply:* > the commit we want to tag is the one on the main branch, yes, that makes sense and should work with any merge method.

matt-SmartBear
2021-08-13 13:31:11

It requires a couple of minor changes to the CHANGELOG format so that we can use a tool to parse it.

matt-SmartBear
2021-08-13 13:31:29

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1567

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1567|#1567 Add a release workflow>
<p><strong>Description</strong></p> <p>Adds an automated release workflow, ref <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common/issues/1688">cucumber/common#1688</a></p> <p><strong>Type of change</strong></p> <p>• Refactoring (improvements to code design or tooling that don't change behaviour)</p> <p><strong>Note to other contributors</strong></p> <p>See the changes in the docs/RELEASE_NOTES.md file.</p> <p>It's going to be difficult to test this without actually doing a release. We could make a 7.0.1 release with nothing in it, just to test the automation.</p> <p><strong>Checklist:</strong></p> <p>Your PR is ready for review once the following checklist is<br /> complete. You can also add some checks if you want to.</p> <p>☐ Tests have been added for any changes to behaviour of the code ☐ New and existing tests are passing locally and on CI ☐ <code>bundle exec rubocop</code> reports no offenses ☐ RDoc comments have been updated ☐ CHANGELOG.md has been updated</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
Jiewen Xiong
2021-08-20 09:36:13

@Jiewen Xiong has joined the channel

Folks, I was on a hackathon team last week that built a GitHub bot to create a link from an issue back to the release when the changelog is updated.

I'd like to start installing this bot in the cucumber org, but I want to take some baby steps. Any objections if I install it in cucumber-ruby-wire? It will spam your inboxes a little bit as it goes over the old issues in the changelog.

2021-10-13 09:15:36

We update changelogs all the time (in-between releases). Does it wait to update relevant issues until the changelog entries have been released? (i.e. when they are no longer under the Unreleased header?)

matt-SmartBear
2021-10-13 10:09:44

Aurélien Reeves
2021-10-14 07:54:11

@Aslak Hellesøy What I did with the compatibility kit would allow to validate cucumber with something as simple as that: ```require 'cucumber-compatibility-kit'

describe 'Cucumber Compatibility Kit' do let(:cucumberbin) { './bin/cucumber' } let(:cucumbercommonargs) { '--publish-quiet --profile none --format message' } let(:cucumbercommand) { "#{cucumberbin} #{cucumbercommon_args}" }

examples = [ 'hooks', 'minimal' ]

examples.each do |examplename| describe "'#{examplename}' example" do includeexamples 'cucumber compatibility kit' do let(:example) { examplename } let(:messages) { #{cucumber_command} --require #{example_path} #{example_path} } end end end end`` From the cucumber-ruby point of view, nothing else than that snippet is required, and it can be part of a singlebundle exec rspec` command.

```$ bundle exec rspec spec/cck .F.F

Failures:

1) Cucumber Compatibility Kit 'hooks' example generates valid message structure Failure/Error: fail "There were comparison errors: #{comparator.errors}"

 RuntimeError:
   There were comparison errors: ["Missing keys in message Cucumber::Messages::Meta: [:protocol_version]", "Found extra keys in message Cucumber::Messages::Hook: [:tag_expression]", "Found extra keys in message Cucumber::Messages::Hook: [:tag_expression]"]
 Shared Example Group: "cucumber compatibility kit" called from ./spec/cck/hooks_spec.rb:15
 # /home/aurelien/cucumber/cucumber/compatibility-kit/ruby/lib/shared_examples.rb:34:in `block (2 levels) in &lt;top (required)&gt;'

2) Cucumber Compatibility Kit 'minimal' example generates valid message structure Failure/Error: fail "There were comparison errors: #{comparator.errors}"

 RuntimeError:
   There were comparison errors: ["Missing keys in message Cucumber::Messages::Meta: [:protocol_version]"]
 Shared Example Group: "cucumber compatibility kit" called from ./spec/cck/hooks_spec.rb:15
 # /home/aurelien/cucumber/cucumber/compatibility-kit/ruby/lib/shared_examples.rb:34:in `block (2 levels) in &lt;top (required)&gt;'

Finished in 1.8 seconds (files took 0.07451 seconds to load) 4 examples, 2 failures

Failed examples:

rspec './spec/cck/hooksspec.rb[1:1:2]' # Cucumber Compatibility Kit 'hooks' example generates valid message structure rspec './spec/cck/hooksspec.rb[1:2:2]' # Cucumber Compatibility Kit 'minimal' example generates valid message structure```

2021-11-05 07:44:14

matt-SmartBear
2021-11-05 07:51:43

*Thread Reply:* Do you need any more feedback? It looks like you have a couple of puzzles from your concluding comment

Aurélien Reeves
2021-11-05 08:11:53

*Thread Reply:* Indeed, if you have some responses regarding the last two points here, it would be welcome: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1566#issuecomment-961007372

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/pull/1566#issuecomment-961007372|Comment on #1566 Upgrade rubocop>
<p>So, to summarize:</p> <p>What we could do as part of dedicated PR (I would open dedicated issues to make sure we do not forget those):</p> <p>• removing the unused <code>_=nil</code> from <code>cli::main#initialize</code> parameter list in v8 • allowing inner slashes in RegexpLiteral rubocop configuration • <code>formatter/ansicolor.rb</code> need to be refactored • removing <code>DataTable#map_column!</code> in v8 which was planned to be removed in v2 • refactor fake modules and classes in <code>configuration_spec.rb</code>, <code>http_io_spec.rb</code>, <code>junit_spec.rb</code> and <code>fake_objects.rb</code> to prevent defining those fakes globally</p> <p>To merge the current PR:</p> <p>• make sure that calling <code>super</code> in the events <code>initialize</code> methods is safe as part of the actual PR (<code>lib/cucumber/events/step_activated.rb</code> and <code>lib/cucumber/events/step_definition_registered.rb</code>) • can we safely delete some code from <code>proto_world.rb</code>? I am still confused with this. It seems to be useless. What would make it useful? <code>Cucumber::Glue#steps</code> and <code>Cucumber::Glue#inspect</code> are just calling <code>super</code> without any other code.</p> <p>Did I missed something? Does that look like a plan?</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
matt-SmartBear
2021-11-05 07:42:13

@luke thanks for all your attention reviewing the 157 changes!

luke
2021-12-15 06:40:44

Not a biggie. But "something" recently has changed the cucumber loggers value of level.

luke
2021-12-15 06:40:46

from 1 to 0.

luke
2021-12-15 06:40:53

which means quite a lot more info is thrown out now by default.

Aurélien Reeves
2021-12-15 06:49:14

Did you identified a commit? Or something?

Aslak Hellesøy
2021-12-15 06:50:04

What logger? I didn't think cucumber had a logger at all? @luke

luke
2021-12-15 06:55:12

ah hang on I think I've spotted it.

luke
2021-12-15 06:55:25

Let me just test something.

yeh we do have a logger. It's from ancient times (10+ years ago).

luke
2021-12-15 06:56:55

Yep so it's interesting. It's a piece of code which has been in cucumber for 10+ years, and I've never once seen. But now for some reason, just recently (like last 2 months), it's been activated as Jetbrains have altered their default run command.

luke
2021-12-15 06:57:10

thought they might have shouted more about this, but oh well.

luke
2021-12-15 06:57:43

jetbrains now pass in an argument to their cucumber execution which turns our logger level up to max, which then dumps a fair bit of information to the console.

😀 Aurélien Reeves
Aslak Hellesøy
2021-12-15 06:57:59

Got a link to the logger?

luke
2021-12-15 06:58:59

https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/lib/cucumber.rb

<https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/main/lib/cucumber.rb | cucumber.rb>
<pre><code># frozen_string_literal: true require 'yaml' require 'cucumber/encoding' require 'cucumber/platform' require 'cucumber/runtime' require 'cucumber/cli/main' require 'cucumber/step_definitions' require 'cucumber/term/ansicolor' module Cucumber class &amp;lt;&amp;lt; self attr_accessor :wants_to_quit, :use_legacy_autoloader def logger return @log if @log @log = Logger.new($stdout) @log.level = Logger::INFO @log end def logger=(logger) @log = logger end end end </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby">cucumber/cucumber-ruby</a>
luke
2021-12-15 06:59:30
